text: The first time I started climbing was at this location and thought it was really fun even though I wasn't able to finish V0. At the time I was afraid of heights. That fear hasn't gone away. TIP: Just go up until you are done. At least when I've been to this location, it's rarely ever crowded which is great because my home gym in Sunnyvale feels like Disneyland. The lines can get long when waiting for routes to climb or even bouldering. This location is a bit smaller but never did I have to ask if a person was switching or not. That was nice for a change. There are two bouldering areas and the fitness area is all upstairs. I've taken the yoga classes here and I really like taking it with Nadia. I use to go to Doris's classes too at Sunnyvale, but it's hard getting up for that 6:15am class. However her core yoga class is great for the hip flexors. Never noticed how helpful it was until I got on the overhang walls.PARKING: Street parking or if you go down a block there's a parking lot on 43rd ave.

This is an updated review for the yoga classes. I used to be snobbish and sworn to only go to dedicated yoga studios. After I went through teacher's training last summer, some of my yogi classmates highly recommended trying out a few classes at PG. I took Nadia and Doris classes, oh dear, they are not for the faint hearted! These yoga classes are geared towards conditioning the core for climbing, target strengthening of climbing muscle groups ( e.g. hip flexors, glutes), as well as functional movement patterns that mimics climbing. I come out of these classes more broken (in a good way) than a hard climbing session. One of the best teachers I've ever had (Edwina) as well as my classmate (Jen) are both teachers there, which says a lot about the high calibre of yoga instructors here. Now, I take majority of my yoga classes at PG and looking forward to trying AcroYoga in a few weeks.

It's not a bad gym. However, considering the pricing for similar climbing gyms on day passes and membership, it is somewhat lacking.This location offers a boulder wall, moonboard without LEDs, and substantial settings for top rope / lead. Every top rope route has an assigned GriGri to belay with. Planet Granite does not offer rope for lead. I was told that the chain was working on rolling it out soon, but as of December 10th this is not yet available. This is apparent in the settings as well - it is very much top rope oriented, and there are no lead exclusive routes. Lead climbers will have to bring their own rope and belay device.Overall, very beginner-oriented gym. Newcomers have to watch a five minute video to orient them to gym etiquette. Equipment is set up in a way to be redundant (which is good).

We've only been here twice for the drop in rock climbing for kids. The check in process both times were quick and painless (booked via phone). The instructors we've had were awesome - great at explaining gear and options and very encouraging and supporting during climbs. My daughter always has so much fun and asks to go back often. They have various paths of difficulty and the instructor will choose the next path based on the kid's feedback after each one. It's so great that they let parents come in and watch so that we can get photos/videos of their kids.

(Bouldering only) Very interesting how different gyms can be so different. My current home gym is Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville, MA, but I was in San Mateo for a weekend so stopped by PG for an afternoon. I think PG's bouldering is better than Brooklyn Boulders (BKB), it feels like the problems are more idiomatic and interesting, rather than being short versions of top-rope climbs. It has more natural "rock" feel walls (BKB has an interesting wood laminate), more surface crevices and corners, meaning potential stemming and fun techniques like that (little potential to practice stemming at BKB); and most of the problems go to the top of the wall; none do on the main wall at BKB.These walls are also super dense and filled with so many problems, which is good and bad. Good if you have the wall to yourself, but bad if it's at all crowded because so many problems are blocked. It's also the first time that I noticed holds from other routes getting in the way of your climb. (But that's not necessarily a bad thing, it's perhaps more "natural"?)They also had more interesting holds types. My favorite were these shallow jug-types that felt secure, but were too shallow to grip past the first knuckle. I felt that this is good training for different parts of the grip. They also had a very interesting green cylinder type hold, that I felt forced you to do monkey-bar style climbing, which was fun.Great staff and impressively stocked retail area. The men's locker room was huge! And the trad gym equipment looked pretty solid.

Not my favourite PG location, but they do a solid job there.  Although not as commodious as other PG locations, they really maximize the space and set a lot of quality routes.  I went on a week day morning, so everything was open, but I can see how it can get crazy in such a small space during a busy time.  We had fun at Planet Granite Belmont on our day off, and if we lived in the area, I'm certain we would return.
Love this gym. Friendly employees and great climbing. It's a bit smaller than Sunnyvale and Portland but that means it's less crowded which is a good thing.

This is definitely one if my favorite places to spend time. Lots of cool people and good climbing/yoga/sauna. I spend hours here each time I come. Only complaint is that the showers are too often flooded with filthy water and hair. Please clean more often guys! Still love this place regardless.

Took the Belay class and it was supposed to start at 4:30 but we started at 5:30 or so because someone called in sick. The guy that taught us was a little obnoxious too. He looked like he just wanted to go home which is pretty dangerous considering that none of us know what we're doing. We got to climb and practice after though which was good. But then when we took the test the day after, all the questions were so vague. Like "what do you wanna make sure of when you see the ropes?" I COULD SAY A BILLION THINGS... Also the guy that taught us how to belay apparently didn't teach us the correct way to break because I did that during my test and the lady said I did it wrong the entire time... I was so confused.

My wife, who has some climbing experience, suggested that we would see if we would enjoy indoor climbing. We looked up this place and decided to sign up for an introduction class (intro for me, fresh up for her). Having a toddler usually prevents us from doing things like this, but this time we felt adventurous and the three of us went to Planet Granite.When we arrived there the friendly team welcomed us and signed us in. I needed shoes, so we went through a couple of sizes until I had a pair that didn't make my toes curl. Who would've thought that my climbing-shoe-size is 3.5 larger than my usual size? (Next Time i probably get one half a size bigger).Michael was our trainer for the day. And we have to give him a lot of credit. Having a toddler that comments everything she sees, wants her parents attention, and cries because she's to tired next to us must've been very challenging. He was so patience with our situation and often explained things multiple times. We didn't feel as he was judging us and even accommodated a second trainer to do some of the exercised with us.From what I can judge the infrastructure seemed new, the trainers knew what they're talking about, and other people enjoy their time at (or on?) Planet Granite.5 stars because I have nothing to complain about and lack of knowledge what I could complain  about.
And update with regards to the reply from the business - I saw a white guy registering using nickname! Sorry but lying is not going to help out.

5 stars for Tyler!I went in about a half hour before closing to take a belay test. Tyler was helpful with the exam, which I passed just fine (but Tyler even gave me a few easy tips to remember everything for the future). When I asked if I could then purchase a day pass to join my friends for the last 20 minutes or so, Tyler was kind enough to let me in, with gear, for nothing at all. It was so sweet. I have been back multiple times because of it (and purchase a day pass each time). Thanks, Tyler!

Planet Granite Belmont requires that visitors go through more rigmarole in order to start climbing than any other gym I've visited. They require all guests, even frequent climbers, to watch a 5 minute orientation video. Also, if someone makes a mistake filling out the waiver form (which I did, I accidentally put the wrong state-of-issue for my driver's license) then they have to go through the entire process again. This overhead is really frustrating if you only have 90 minutes or so to visit.

Several months ago, I got into rock climbing, which convinced me to get a membership here at Planet Granite, and it did not disappoint.  I can climb here but there are also so many more things that the place offers.First of all, there are climbing walls (duh, haha) for bouldering, top roping, lead climbing, tons of stuff.  I like bouldering on my own and then top roping with a partner or a group.  The only thing is, at least one person must be certified to belay if you want to top rope.  If you have no one with the belay license or if you are climbing alone, the two bouldering caves are both great.  The routes are updated every couple months, but they never get old because there are SO MANY to do!  Lots of challenging routes at every level for any climber, no matter how much experience they have.Then there are the yoga and fitness classes.  These are free with a membership, but you can also take them if you buy a daypass or use a member's guest pass.  The instructors are super great at helping you reach whatever fitness goals you are hoping for, and they are very knowledgable and caring about what they do.  The gym upstairs is great, too -- lots of equipment and space to work out. And if you're running on the treadmills, the second story location allows you to overlook the rest of the building, and you can watch the climbers as they go up the walls.  A nice way to pass the time if you're running :)A recommendation I have is, if possible, come before 3 PM.  If you come after that, there are a lot of kids that make the place very crowded and a bit hectic, because they have gotten out of school at that point.  And the same goes for work hours -- if you want to beat the crowds, come before 6PM or else the after work crowd will meet you there!All in all, I LOVE PG and definitely recommend getting a day pass here at least once.  And, let me tell you, that'll soon lead to a membership.  You'll love it!! :)

A solid reliable option for climbing in the area. I normally go to the PG in the city but stopped by here on the way up from the south bay. This gym is smaller then their SF location but its cozy and quality of the routes were good. Their bouldering area is split up to 2 sections but it feels like 2 cozy bouldering caves. not too high or big but enough to get a good work out. Their top rope selection was pretty solid. lots a routes with plenty of features to use. The workout area was really large and had a good selection of workout equipment.

Harriet's core and fitness classes are the best. She makes up a new playlist for each class and each class is different. Her classes are so wonderful that most of the people who take her class are gym members just to go to her classes.
Great staff and facilities.   The trainer is clearly passionate about the sport.  Gave great instructions to my son and was very patient.

Came to PG as an experienced climber myself (I've been bouldering a total of two times in the past...../sarcasm) with my two friends who were first timers. $25 for a day pass and $5 for shoes - which in reality, you are paying $30 for 2 hours because your hands will probably fall off afterwards if you haven't already developed calluses on them yet. Only $2 extra if you want to learn how to belay....we didn't take advantage of it, but hey, if you're interested, it's only $2 more so that you can rock climb!The front desk attendants were helpful. After signing the waiver, we watched a five minute video on the basics of bouldering. After that.....off into the gym we go! They have two bouldering rooms - one to the left and one to the right. To be honest, we didn't know that we could go into the one to the left because the lights weren't on (I don't know if there are even lights in there....?) so we stayed mainly to the right. There are a good amount of routes in that room itself so it should probably keep you occupied for the most part. I've always heard that the rock climbing community is extremely nice and supportive, and based on the few people we met here, I agree with that! And lastly, we weren't sure if we could park in the parking lot next to PG since it was really more connected to the auto shop, so street parking could be a little iffy.Can't wait to climb again so I can conquer the V2's (don't laugh at me....)... but rock climbing gyms, imo, are expensive af.

I mainly boulder here.The areas are small but the setting quality and the volume of climbs per wall is great. The people are very friendly as well. They also have a Moon board on the top floor!!!My main gripe is that there are hella people bouldering in their street shoes. These are mainly new climbers and they don't know... but I feel like the gym should address how unsanitary this is.

I am now a member. I usually do bouldering because I think it's more fun. I think it'll be good if you could have a line to put not-climbing people put in a safer region without being hit by falling people. It can also bring climbing people more confidence and safety when they challenge themselves without worrying about hurting others.
Been going to this gym for two years now. Great staff. Fun climbs. Decent machine and weight area upstairs.
Damn this place! I didn't know rock climbing could be so much fun! I attended Intro to climbing: Belay lesson, and it was good. Huge space with lotta options. And friendly staff.
Just walked in and reserved my belay class for myself and my girlfriend. Was greeted and helped by Caden, who was professional, kind, and efficient. Excellent service. Thank you Caden!

Updating after a year and a half -After my rant of the gym area back in Aug 2016, the staff reached out to me to discuss my issues with the gym. There were some simple items that were fixed in the following weeks - broken leg extension replaced and smith machine replaced with a squat rack. The gym manager at the time had lots of ideas on how to improve the lifting area but he was transferred within a couple weeks.The new gym manager, Evan, and the staff for 2017/2018, much praise to them! I noticed new gym equipment would start showing up and new upholstery on the benches, but in January 2018, they finally made it happen - all bumper plates except for a couple steels. It was Christmas in January for us regulars! We still can't do oly lifts and drop the weights, so I just keep it under control. Only complain is they took away too much of the steel plates so there's only one pair of steel 45s and 10 pairs of 45 bumpers. There is plenty of bumpers for everyone.It's nice to know that the staff and the gym manager taking our complaints seriously. There's still a couple guys that doesn't know how to rack their weights (because honestly, some climbers seem to be in their own little world sometimes, but that's a rant of another time), so I just make them wait while I take my time in the racks or benches.It's a good gym with updated locker rooms/restrooms and if you're a regular, the people are friendly - you just need to break into the individual high school-like cliques. If you're a regular lifter, you can join mine
Best place to unwind after work. Love the fitness classes that planet granite offers . No matter how hard your day was planet granite experience never fails to make you feel good about yourself .

Just went here the other day and as we arrive it took two people to figure out how to find my friend in the system, for them to say she's never been to this gym before, even though she was previously a member, then needed to sign a waiver again, and they said she didn't have her belay card on file and wanted to retest her, when she showed them the card from the Belmont gym and promptly corrected them. Then they offered to change her 10 pack to a digital card, but with all the mishaps in checking in, she refused.While I waited I decided to take the belay test, since I am relatively new to PG. The woman I had was pretty condescending. I do know all the safety requirements, I've been outdoor belaying and belaying at other gyms, she was looking for particular words vs knowledge on what to do, so she said she'd only give me a day pass. The climbing itself ended up being really fun. I have gone climbing at other gyms, and have never experienced such awful customer service. This experience with the gym staff definitely soured my opinion on it.
Even when it's busy there is space to climb and workout. When I see everyone walking around with their bare feet I think of two things: foot fungus and plantar warts. I always keep my shoes on.

Decent sized rock climbing gym located right off El Camino. There's not a lot of parking along the side street next to the gym, so I would recommend parking in the neighboring plaza lot.Overall, this rock climbing gym is a great place to climb/work out, whether you're a beginner or a seasoned rock climber. The gym has climbing grades ranging from 5.5. to 5.13 and boulder grades ranging from v0 to v10+. Ratings here are on the softer side, and I would highly recommend coming if it's your first time climbing, as the atmosphere is friendly and the staff are attentive. They also offer a number of Intro to Climbing classes every day ($30/class, inclusive of gear + shoe rentals), where they teach you climbing + belaying basics and prepare you to take the belay certification test. Because this is the first Planet Granite location, some of the amenities are older, but they are slowly renovating and improving their amenities. One factor to consider, however, is that Planet Granite is on the more expensive side. A day pass costs $25, and a monthly membership is $90, before the initiation + other fees.

Though I prefer the Sunnyvale and SF location, this location is closer to work so I come here about 2-3 times a week. People are friendly and although it can get quite busy after work, you usually don't have to wait too long for a climb. People here are more laid back than other PG locations so I always have fun and meet tons of new people!

This climbing facility is the worst and unsafest I have ever been to. In fact, the staff brags about how often the ambulance has to come to the gym!!!!  The safety gear is unclean and outdated.  The ropes have been over-stressed and lost their elasticity, which is essential for a safe belay.

I LOVE the fitness classes taught by Harriete!  My family just moved to CA and I was used to doing only CrossFit type workouts and Harriete kicks my butt every class!  She works all of my smaller muscles and core that I never take the time to work on.  I am glad that I found her classes and the class times as it is the perfect start to my day!

Visited this gym on my one week SF trip and loved it here.  Came on a Saturday morning right as they opened and it was not crowded at all.  The bouldering area is smaller than the one at Planet Granite Presidio but for my 1.5 hour bouldering session I had more than enough problems to keep me busy.  Some very creative and fun bouldering problems and the other climbers here are very friendly. My friends joined me for some top rope 1.5 hours later and I really enjoyed the the long routes too.  My gym (BKB Chicago) only has smooth walls so the texture of the PG walls is very different to me but it's nice to try out different styles.Around 11:15AM when we left, the gym started getting busier than most routes you have to wait.  Can't wait to come back again... hopefully soon.

Started coming here 2 mos ago and the family is hooked. Have since checked out another gym on a trip and realized that we are very lucky to have clean holdsthat arenot super smooth and slippery and also that are color coordinated (vs tape markings). Precidio location is much larger but Belmont totally suits my needs and the staff is really great!

I've been coming here for the past 2 months now. I come here during the mornings and early afternoons. Since my joining, I've seen nothing but daily construction work in this gym. As a result, it obstructs any chance to do any bouldering because of the obstruction (see pictures). I get that you need to update and put new routes, but can't this be done at night when no one is here? Why do the morning people have to sacrifice their hours for this? If you like bouldering, this is the worst gym for it.

Rock climbing is always a great idea! Whether you want to go on a friendly date, you want to tire out your kids, try something new with friends, or just get a good workout it this is the place to go. It may not look like much on the outside, but I side they've got a weight room, machines, tons of bikes and treadmills, 2 bouldering nooks (rock climbing without the rope attached) and of course the rock walls themselves. The service is ok, not very attentive, but they know what they're doing. And just in case you dont, they have plenty of classes covering a variety of exercises. You can, also, rent or buy equipment, and the prices are very reasonable! Only downfall there is no pool, but hey, if you're not gonna need it why have it, right?
Planet Granite Belmont is where I met my friends and we totally became a climbing family. PGB has a great vibe. I hope it never changes!
Not the MOST extensive climb terrain in the bay but a great community and usually pretty empty so great for training.

The first customer service is cool but after you've gone through check in and all you're pretty much on your on. Feel free to ask questions because you can get a lil lost .  You need special certification to do the big climbing. They have a couple areas for boulder climbing you can do without it tho.  They have a great workout area. It's pretty much a full workout area. They have special event nights that are pretty cool too.  The parking isn't as bad as it used to be, it's actually pretty good. They have stumptown coffee here too.

Been a member at this gym for over 4 years, and I can't say this gym is changing. The crowds at this gym at getting larger. Most of the time the gym is packed. I use the weight/ fitness area upstairs often. I used to love using their pull-up bars, but now it seems that the "climbing team" (mostly composed of young children) are always in the fitness area using all of the pull-up bar equipment. I can no longer practice calisthenics on the weekdays at this gym. ***updated review 5th time this month I have had to leave what I was doing because of the climbing team... these kids should not be allowed upstairs.The showers usually stink. Climbing facilities are cool, I like using them when it's not crowded. Best times to use this gym is probably in the AM. Last, and I think this is fair to list, but membership cost are high and have consistently increased every year since I've been a member.

Ah, PG, I used to love thee (although a little less now that I lift more and climb less).It's pricey and an older facility, but because it IS a specialized gym for a sport that you can't do 'just anywhere', they charge way more than expected.  Membership to one PG grants you access to any of their family of gyms (San Francisco Presidio, Sunnyvale, Portland, and Belmont). Their hours are extremely broad, meaning you'll be sure to find a time during your work week to drop by.They offer belay lessons to all newcomers (as you must be certified before you can top rope), which are pretty helpful. Every Wednesday (unless it's a holiday) or so, they put up new routes on a certain section of the wall, so you're always going to run into something new.They also offer yoga lessons, and upstairs is a decently equipped (albeit dusty) gym.My biggest complaint is how little love the lifting area upstairs is given. The equipment is limited in number and is shoved into a small room, making it difficult for more than a few people to use the weights at once. There's only one bench press and one squat rack, so wait times can be high. The manager had said that he was going to bring in new equipment, but that was some time ago, doesn't seem like it's going to happen.It can get quite crowded on weekends, but it's at least a great community of people.UPDATE: They raised membership fees, but still have broken equipment around with promises of repairs from nearly 1 year ago, and almost 2 years worth of empty promises about updating the weight lifting space. It's a little disappointing :/Tl;dr: a good climbing community, but not a well-equipped place for anything else.

"He's climbing the rope, and he's gaining."  -- The Princess Bride (1987)What a great rock-climbing gym. Nice and spacious, plenty of staffers around to help out, and the facility is clean and well-organized.  I've been here a few times to bring my niece for her classes/camp.  Her camp had 5 or 6 girls in it and they each got to climb at their own level with the counselor/instructor.  Here is my only complaint: this guy was not really engaged. When the girls were climbing, he was texting on his cell phone (with who, I have no idea) and had a hard time managing 6 Tweens. My guess is he was early 20's and maybe didn't sign up for this.  He never dropped anyone (he was belaying for them all), but he was also easily irritated. Surprising he wasn't more attentive considering I was standing right there as a parent. My niece also said she disliked when this kid was her teacher.  Update: she quit going to camp.Now, let's talk positives. My niece also had her birthday party at this location. Now, this they handled beautifully.  We had a couple of even younger (seemingly) young ladies help out with belaying, plus we brought our own certified helper (thanks Helen F.) so more kids could climb at a time. PG was cool with it, so the kids went to town.We didn't have the place to ourselves by any means, but seriously it certainly felt like we had the run of the joint. We had no real limitations.  The kids had a blast and the adults got to climb some too.  I think this is a great place to have a kids a party - the kids are active and they handle it well.I will say that we went around the corner to a pizza joint for dinner and dessert, just as an FYI.

Oh my lord I dislike this PG so much. Maybe I'm spoiled because I've got the PG in SF as my stomping ground, but BOY THIS PG COULD USE SOME SERIOUS WORK. First off, LOCATION IS SUCKY. It's on a busy street and the parking situation is confusing. I'm still confused. 5 hours later. Still scratching my head at where everyone parks when they climb here. There's not really a parking lot for this PG; there's one next door but I think it's for the autoshop. Street parking is iffy because it's on a crazy busy street. WHERE DO PEOPLE PARK???? HALP LOL. The gym itself? Small. Cramped. Stuffy. All the things you don't want when you think of gym. The front lobby is essentially a third of the gym. There are only two bouldering sections, basically little alcoves on opposite ends of the gym. BARELY any space. If you've been to PG SF or Sunnyvale, Belmont is like a quarter of the size. There's no breathing room. And since it's so tiny, it reeks. It just smells like a stinky climbing gym ya know. And the women's locker room isn't any better. The facility seems very outdated. There is gym equipment upstairs though, overlooking the rest of the climbing walls. Maybe they get better ventilation up there from being purely higher up than all the clogged, smelly air downstairs.I was bouldering the day I went there and it started to get pretty busy around 7ish so I left. But I usually climb V2's at PG SF & Sunnyvale. I was doing V3 here so either I got better overnight or the routes are a little easier here LOL. I think it's the latter. Overall, probably the worst PG location I've been to. But that doesn't mean PG is bad. I LOVE PG. SF. SUNNYVALE. YOU GUYS ROCK. The facilities are great. Belmont -- not so much. If you want to try indoor climbing, go to another gym instead of Belmont. There are far better options.

I signed up for the gym and yoga/fitness classes. For the monthly unlimited price, the value is exceptional. The quality of yoga classes is high, in comparison to other studios. The ambiance is peaceful. The gym does get packed during peak times, so I'd always try to go during work hours (but I'm self-employed, so that's reasonable). Overall vibe is wonderful with down to earth employees and people. Instructors will often walk around during non-class hours to try to teach PG members about their classes and encourage participation. Clearly, they take pride in their work and care about creating a great experience.I can also tell that people really care about the community here. It's great to see a gym where the leadership team really cares about quality while still keeping price points reasonable for lots of different people. I've never felt nickeled and dimed, like I have at places like the Bay Club.The upstairs gym isn't awesome, but it *is* good for a basic workout, if you're not looking for anything fancy. I think everything is very well-cared for given the foot traffic that this business has.

I've been a member of PG for years, and kept coming back by joining a fantastic climbing community that feels more like a family after all this time.PROs.- The climbing routes here are challenging, well thought out, and technical- Some of the friendliest people come here to climb, lift, or yogi it up- There are regular community events and climbing comps- Membership at one PG gives you access to all locations (Sunnyvale, SF, Portland)CONs.- Weight machines that break tend to stay broken (there's one that's been 'out of order' for the past 3 months, with no fix in sight)- Upper gym area has some uneven flooring issues, especially in the weight room - It's a specialty gym, so it can be a bit steep (~70/month)Ultimately it comes down to the fact that PGB comes with the highs and lows of being a specialized gym with no competition mid-peninsula, but the sense of community here is what truly makes the Belmont gym shine.

This review is for Danae Robinett's wonderful yoga Vinyasa on Sunday mornings 9:30am Planet Granite  Belmont.   Her class is playful and encouraging.   She takes proper alignment seriously,  but encourages the class to have fun.   Class difficulty is adjusted by Danae according to the class makeup on each day. Highly recommend this class.

This used to be a 3 star joint.  I would think Sunnyvale could fund Belmont in its revenue alone.  Even if that is not so, why is Belmont so junky. Before it used to be limited wall space and not as fun to explore any routes.Now Belmont is dirty. I skipped a skirt and wig but I would have a hard time to believe the lady's locker room is a whole lot cleaner. The boy's room smelled like the carpets have not been cleaned.  Body order, sweat, and a longer list of organisms that I care not to mention (and where these organisms stem from). Fans, bleach, and carpet cleaner are possible solutions.Please use your revenue wisely.

I've been climbing at this gym on and off for over 5 years now and I still love it! They have a variety of climbing problems for all levels of experience/ability which makes it a great place to bring both experienced, and new climbers. The upstairs gym has just about everything one can ask for, plus it looks out over the climbing walls. They also have 2 bouldering areas. The only downside is that parking can be challenging at busy times, unless you want to brave the gnarly hill around the corner. It's steeper than it looks. Anyways, happy climbing!

I've been a member for about a year now.  I have a few observations.The Good:- excellent fitness classes including crossfit, yoga, cycling, core with flexible schedules- excellent weight lifting amenities (endless barbells, weights ,squat racks etc)- best top route / lead climbing gym in the Bay Area bar none- formidable bouldering problems- excellent instructors for climbing and fitness- great, helpful environment and community for new climbers- many members only perks and social events- walk-ins allowed on a member guest pass or paid day pass- free climbing lessons for friends if you are a memberThe Not So Good:- peak hours are incredibly busy; there are waits for every climb- sometimes they run out of lockers during busy times- parking is horrible; there is no better way to put it; way too many cars and way too small of a lot during peak times- may be a bit of a wait for lifting equipment during busy hoursOverall, my experience here has been incredibly positive.  I've made lots of friends, learned to be a better climber, and have increased my overall fitness and quality of life.  At first, I thought the membership fee was a bit steep compared to somewhere like 24 Hour Fitness or City Sport, but PG really has a much more community feel and the caliber of instruction here is just so much better.

I've been coming here weekly for 6 months now and LOVE it! The actual facility is pretty old and beat up with leaky roofs (which I think is in the process of being fixed soon), but the employees do a great job maintaining it. I used to come in the middle of the day and would always see employees sanitizing every piece of equipment! Employees here are super friendly and welcoming. Honestly think they are the nicest compared to SF and Sunnyvale too! I think people tend to hate on Belmont because the facility is a lot smaller and older, but it's also not nearly as crowded as the other locations. I will admit that the gym membership is pricey, but I like the option of having the climbing section, weight area, and yoga. I'd recommend people interested in signing up for a membership to wait for that awesome Groupon deal! It gives you free equipment rentals and waives your initiation fee so its super worth it. Can't wait to come back and climb on :)

Late review, was here a few months ago and I had a great time. Had some friends talk me into rock climbing so I finally decided to take some time out and try it. Parking was easy, staff is friendly and they have a gym upstairs. Thanks Zoey for helping us out on our first rock climbing experience. We'll be back again very soon.

Last night was the first time I've climbed at the PG in Belmont (pretty regular at both the Sunnyvale & SF gyms). While the gym is a lot smaller than the other two, I was sufficiently impressed with the number and varied difficulty of the routes they've been able to fit in the space.Not only was there a good mix of routes, but there are possibly more lead routes here than the other gyms (so much of the top rope space is available to lead) which is really awesome. I need to get a new rope so I can check out some of those routes!The only down side to this gym is the parking situation - no parking lot, street parking only. But given it's in Belmont there wasn't an issue finding a street spot so not sure if this is a big deal.I'll be back, many more routes to explore!

Great great way to work out your body and challenge yourself. I went here since two of my fiends were members and they wanted me to try it. The place is clean and you can tell who the regulars are. The staff is very driest and ensure you know all re safety precautions. If ya your first time rock climbing, you'll take a mandatory hour training with thee folks and learn about climbing, tying knots, and releasing rope for the climber. Staff do not take this lightly.The walls have different levels and it takes a certain technique to do rock climbing. It's best to be with someone who's is experience so that you gain all you can in your one day session. They have bells at the top of the walls and people stuck their name badges up there for bragging rights. Loved it!

The wall is great. Very contoured and intricate. The climbing experience was great overall.My gripe with the place was with this pretentious and rude staff member that wasted an hour of my time. Ive been to many gyms and this experience was by far the worst. I watched as maybe 15 other people got helped while I sat waiting. Don't go here if you appreciate respect.

This is merely a money making business. It lacks any higher purpose. If you want to rock climb for any other reason (care about nature, or other human beings sharing space on this planet, for instance) look elsewhere. A more fitting name: "Planet Ego," if you are looking to pay a lot of money to be treated like dirt, you've found the right place.

I love this gym for multiple reasons!1) close to work...It allows me to dodge traffic..2) I usually have no trouble finding parking3) Love the Tuesday Yoga taught by Josie Zhou4) Top ropes comes in multiple level and accommodates climbers of all levels5) Fitness center is large enough that it doesn't feel over crowded6) Class times actually fits my schedule7) Bathrooms and changing areas are clean8) Staffs are nice and helpfulOnly wish they had more of a discount. Kinda pricey for membership and even more expensive for drop ins.

Although this location is small, it's perfect for beginners.  The instructor, forgot his name, sorry!, was down to earth, honest, and made me feel at ease.  The one tip that I found very useful that other facilities didn't give was to just fall.  One of my fears was falling and and having my partner catch me at the last minute but this tip helped me conquer that fear.Tips:-Lockers are available but BYOL(lock) or use the open cubbies to store your things-Shoes are provided; you are required to wear a size smaller than your regular size-There's a water fountain to quench your thirst-Bring your workout gloves to get your workout on after climbing-Plenty of street parkingI recommend signing up for the package that's offered before/after your class.  It's 5 class for $55.

Great place to boulder for the day! And I am a huge fan of the rock conveyor belt... especially the incline part. They have belaying and classes here too and a weight section. I enjoy the cave as well for a bit of stretching and climbing. So much fun! Would go back anytime I visit Atlanta :)

Liked it. Airy. Clean. Pretty tall. Empty during work hours. Everyone that comes in during that time is solo n goes to the fitness area. The routes r really fun!  All levels. Kudos for the setters. Friendly and knowledgeable staff. Always cleaning the place. Well run place!

Of all the Planet Granite's, this location is the smallest but the emptiest. It was totally empty at 5pm on a weekday (mostly kids), and got pretty crowded at around 7:30pm. There are more tall walls and interesting wall configurations for top rope. I also think the course setters make everything easier than other gym's, I climbed my first 5.11d. So awesome. They have cool classes and plenty of machines. The locker room is a bit cramped, but they have all the essentials - shower, lockers, a couple bathrooms, and a sauna.  Also, people are really nice here. Would definitely return and make this a regular gym if I was closer.

In terms of top roping this place is great! They have walls of varying heights and routes of varying difficulty. The staff is quite friendly and helpful and they offer belay lessons for those that need it. For the belay lessons plan ahead because they get filled up fast. They have two bouldering sections, the grading for both are definitely not as soft as the gym I'm used to climbing at. The walls are also shorter than I'm used to but the routes are still fun. Not sure how often they reset but it's nice to have the option to Boulder. The gym itself is surprisingly very well developed. They offer a much of weight machines, rowing machines, rings, cardio machines, free weights, yoga room and even squat racks. If I didn't work at a gym I would highly consider making this my go to gym. They have a couple groupon deals and student discounts as well but are strict about who qualifies as a student.  Drop in price is $20 which is a lot more than I'm used to but also pretty typical for a climbing gym.Beware, parking can be hard to find!

Wish Planet Granite was closer so it could be my go to gym.  Front desk personnel were friendly helpful educated and hard working. There were about 4 people people behind the counter and each person busy either with supplies, check ins, training new customers on climbing or checking on people putting on climbing shoes.  Our party of four wanted to go bouldering. We climbed for a good 3.5 hours and had a blast.  This gym has regular workout equipment upstairs, a yoga studio, 2 bouldering rooms and a central area dedicated to belaying.  It can get quite crowded because this gym is smaller than most of the other Planet granite locations. Highly recommend this experience.

This location is nice for ROCK CLIMBING and not so much of bouldering. By now, I'm sure you've heard that the Sunnyvale location is bigger than Belmont one and that is definitely true. As I come just for the bouldering, I came at the wrong time this week. It so happens they had a competition so one of the side walls remodeled to accommodate and thus, it wasn't back to the normal V0 and on. They only had one side of the wall. In addition, I came at like their peak hour so it was really crowded with people. Overall, there's plenty of rock climbing space and a nice gym upstairs, too. There's nothing wrong with this place, but as someone who just boulders, I'm more used to going to places with the entire place set up for bouldering.

Not comparing it to the other locations, this is an excellent climbing gym. Fairly large area, two bouldering rooms, wide variety of top rope levels, gym equipment on the second floor, and yoga classes. Climbing lessons of varying kinds offered for beginners and more advanced climbers. Rental gear available so you can come with just your will to go vertical. Also, one of the best parts for me, is the other climbers are generally very friendly and courteous. You can find help if you're struggling without looking hard.

The Belmont Planet Granite is filed under "Gyms, yoga" but maybe should have an additional category of "playground" or maybe "babysitter services" (??)Discovery #1: Planet Granite has a "climb and dine" every other Friday, 6:00-8:30. We dropped off the kids, and went out for a nice dinner nearby.  Cost was a little steep ($40/kid) and we had to combine with another family to fulfill the minimum of 4 kids. But that's not too far from our total babysitting cost, plus the kids had fun and got some exercise. Both my daughters loved this SO FREEKING MUCH that this led to...Discovery #2: Kids birthday parties!  My youngest turned 7 and, after her experience above, decided this was the place to bring her friends.  For a group of 10 kids, Planet Granite supplied 2 friendly, experienced, teenage instructors. (We were asked to provide one add'l certified belayer beforehand since a few extra children joined the group; Luckily one parent friend qualified).  Kids were all issued helmets, harnesses and safety-briefed. The only problem - no facilities for food/cake here, so at the end we gave kids snacks in the lobby and fed them pizza and cake at home. But everyone had a blast, and it all worked out just fine.I can't say enough about Planet Granite's:-- Commitment to Safety: Enforcing good rules means safe kids-- Staff: My kids bonded with them on both occasions, and they didn't want to leave.

For new users, I highly recommend you STAY AWAY from this location. Customer service is HORRIBLE! My boyfriend is a very experienced rock climber and I am sort of a beginner but I've climbed 10+ times.We had never been so we filled out waivers (at this point they should have given us more information on how they work but they were all too busy texting to bother with that) and they charged us for 2 day passes and shoes. After we paid and got out gear on they told me that because we were "new" we would have to go through a class before we could climb. The class was $28 and didn't start until 3:30 pm. This was about 2 pm, so they expected us to wait on hour and a half. There were plenty of them standing around texting/drinking coffee/etc but they wouldn't give us an overview or let us take a class for AN HOUR AND A HALF! AFTER we signed up and paid. Will not be going back to this location. Highly reccomend staying away.

I've been climbing here for close to 18 months and I have to say it is an excellent gym.  Firstly the staff are super helpful and friendly and incredibly experienced climbers.  Secondly the gym has a great mixed bag of climbing and bouldering routes. The workout area is superb too.  Lots of modern equipment, weights, etc. It's a smaller gym than the Sunnyvale location but that being said it is more intimate and has e a very friendly atmosphere.  Everyone is helpful and considerate as a result.  One of the things I love about it is that there are lots of very good climbers to help you with technique and lots of routes that are changed very frequently so you don't get bored.  Also the holds are cleaned every time so you don't end up with gunky chalky holds (and nasty bacteria!).The routes vary from a small slab wall, to overhangs and longer pitches (~40ft).  There are lots of top-rope routes and mixed in there are sport lead routes to so you have lot's of choice.  It's pretty hard to get bored with the routes !!For all you parents, this gym is super kid friendly.  I believe they have many activities for all ages for teaching kids to climb.  And having kids around livens up the place (as long as they are being safe!).

Been here for about 9 months,I could spend all my afternoons just climbing and hanging out, actually that's what I do.Taken about 10 different friends for free belay classes (perks of being a member)Free guest pass every two months, it use to be every month (like 4 years ago). Bummer.GreAt staff, seems like they vary in experience (which is nice for me because I'm a newb)

Tried a drop in for crossfit. Entry staff were poor and tried to make me do an evaluation class.Evan the crossfit guy was a pretty poor trainer. He looked bored, didn't walk around and coach people but just sat on the sidelines. Lots of people could have benefitted from coaching on their form. Place felt chaotic.Maybe rock climbing is a lot better, don't go here for crossfit.

I have been a member at Planet Granite for just over a year now, and can say that it has been a very painless experience. The staff is always very friendly and accommodating. Lending long time customers a pair of shoes if they forgot them, versus charging them is always a very class act. I have encountered this once or twice at Planet Granite, and it is always very refreshing. It does not feel like they are after your money, what so ever. The facilities are always super clean, and if you are upstairs lifting weights, never very cramped. Machines, barbells and cardio machines are always available.If climbing is your thing, there are plenty of routes with varying levels of difficulty. They have many top rope climbs, as well as two different bouldering rooms. The climbs are updated every month or two, as are the bouldering problems. There are even some super crazy climbs that are set by the gyms signature masochist "Mike A." In addition to the above they do offer yoga and classes, but I personally do not have any experience with them. The bathrooms are clean and well kept up, although the mens bathroom smells horrible and has since joining.

My home gym is the Planet Granite in Sunnyvale, but I've always wanted to stop by Belmont too. I think that the Belmont PG is probably the oldest out of all three gyms. Maybe they are next in line for a remodel! It's a bit smaller, and parking can be really tough because they don't have a dedicated lot. However, those in the know have advised me to park in the lot just one block north. The walls are shorter, but they more than make up for it with the terrain of the walls, which are very different from PG SF and PG SV. There are lots of overhangs and caves that make for some rather challenging climbs. I think that the setters do a great job keeping their routes creative. I noticed a lot of climbs that traversed in order to make the most of the shorter walls. I didn't get a chance to try out the bouldering, but they have two separate, cave-like areas, one of which has a nice skylight. The locker room was stocked with the same amenities you'd find at the other gyms, it was just smaller. PG Belmont also offers yoga and other fitness classes. And their upper level has the same cardio and weight machines that you'd find at the other two gyms. I think that I'm going to try and stop by more often. It was pretty deserted on Saturday morning around 10:30 when I climbed, but the crowds started trickling in by 12:30 when I left.

Got a membership to planet granite and really like the belmont location, mostly for convenience!It doesn't offer as much climbing walls as the sunnyvale location, but it is adequate! They offer yoga classes and other work out classes as well so it just isn't focued on "rock climbing". The front desk is polite and helpful as well.Parking is a bit of a confusing thing- but you can park on the road and you can use the parking spaces the next street past planet granite for free parking! It is definitely worth the cost monthly if you are an avid climber. I wish they changed the rocks more often because that would be more challenging and if you see a rock path with a smiley face theyre a little bit harder than the other ones :)Great place. it has a sauna too which is nice.

A star for the staff - we are usually met with a nice greeting and they are helpful when I have a question. Only one girl who seems fairly new seems constantly annoyed and never smiles. A second star for the climbing - challenging routes and interesting climbs. It's a small gym so you have to keep that in mind, but they do a good job with the resources they have. A star for the sauna - not something everyone is looking for, but I'm happy it's there, especially with the cold weather.Minus a star for the showers. They have people that come in to tidy up, but I don't think anyone ever comes in to do a deep clean. I was going to take off a second star for the lack of better gym equipment upstairs. There are quite a few machines, weights, etc., but only a few great ones. Hopefully they can afford some better ones soon.

I'm a newb. Enticed by a deal I found on groupon I decided to check this place out with two other friends. For $35 we got a belay class, free rentals for a week, and one week unlimited use of the gym.It's a good idea to take the belay class or test if you plan on going with friends. I ended up returning with a friend who didn't take the class so she couldn't belay me. I have a fear of heights so it took me 3 visits to reach the top. After that I ended up having a great time and I'm planning on returning. It also gets very busy on weekday nights but the crowd died down as it got later in the night. I think this is a good place for beginners like me with the exception that there isn't much help after your belay class. My friends and I were all new to climbing so we had lots of questions and no one to ask. I think I may sign up for the BRC class to get more introductory knowledge on rock climbing.It doesn't smell that bad in the climbing areas, but the female locker room smells like nasty feet!

This planet granite needs to step it up! I've climbed in in both SF and Sunnyvale and my most recent job change has forced me to climb here. I'm going to hone in on one of my biggest complaints about this place and that's the bathroom. How long is your sauna going to be out of order!? No matter that I cut my cardio short because I believe that sitting in the sauna is pretty much the same thing... sweat is sweat... right?RIGHT!Also, the communal showers are fine, but when PG's two sisters have stall showers it sets a standard that belmont broke. Maybe SF and Sunnyvale spoiled me, but I should expect less, OR MAYBE PG-Belmont should fix its sauna.

I'm giving Planet Granite Belmont 4 stars because I do not like it as much as Planet Granite Sunnyvale (my review: yelp.com/biz/planet-gran…). It is a lot smaller and less active, and the walls are shorter by 10 feet (50 as opposed to 60 ft). The cleanliness and the quality of the ropes and holds were comparable though, and I did like the routes themselves. The walls had some cool features though not as many as in Sunnyvale, because of the more limited space. The difficulty level was slightly more difficult than the Sunnyvale location. Parking was on the street in a residential area, which was kind of weird. We checked out the climbing wall "treadmill" machine too, which was very hard to use. Definitely more of a novelty than anything. The second floor also has some other gym equipment.Verdict: This was definitely more like a standard rock wall gym than its Sunnyvale counterpart. Good routes but nothing stood out.

I've never rock climbed before and joined a few days ago (using a Groupon - awesome deal)!My body isn't that of a RC as a matter of fact...I'm not in very good shape at all but I will continue to come! It's fun, everyone is very friendly  and I'm actually starting to enjoy it! I truly admire everyone who practices this sport! What a work out...Thank you for the experience Planet Granite...see you later!
Pretty solid gym, good mix of bouldering and top roping.   Interesting fake rock wall too.    The route setting was good, and when i went it wasn't crowded.

Belmont PG is a midway point between SF and Sunnyvale.1)  Location-wise it's very conveniently smack dab in the middle of the Peninsula.2)  It's not as luxurious as PG SF, but it's definitely not as stinky and crowded as PG Sunnyvale. 3)  The classes here are by far my favorites!    Harriett's Abs & Core will destroy you.  Don't be fooled.  The equipment upstairs seems ok and the set-up is interesting - as Scott L. has mentioned, it's great for people watching.They are getting a new bouldering room in August!

I can't not like PG, but I have to not like it because it's so far from me - I'm in East Bay - and it's so damn expensive. I don't have a membership because their gyms are so far and so expensive. But, I take every chance I can to come here and climb. Belmont is not my favorite just because it's so cramped at this gym. There are two small bouldering rooms with plenty of problems, but the area for people to exist in these rooms are miniscule. Always chill staff at PG, but if you are in Belmont and need a solid place to climb, come to PG. I haven't done much top roping at this PG, but it should be just as fun.

I'm used to the Sunnyvale PG, but came out to explore this one with a friend who lives in the area and wanted to try this one out. I don't really boulder, so I'm really just covering the top-roping in this review.Compared to Sunnyvale, it's a much smaller gym, but I feel like they're a lot more creative with their route setting to compensate for that--the routes aren't all a nearly straight vertical climb, and I appreciate that because I'm not yet very good at remembering to look around for other hand/foot-holds. I also like that they have walls that are a little more random than the generally flat panel ones in the center, which resemble the Sunnyvale gym more closely.The staff here seems a little less approachable, but it may simply be that I've interacted with the Sunnyvale staff a lot more from having started out with a couple of classes there, so I kind of know them a bit better than just strangers. The locker room and bathroom here is a bit dated and worn, but seems to be clean enough. Parking is confusing--after coming twice, I am still not sure where to park, but we've managed by finding street parking or parking in the lot for the car shop next door. I think they have a fabled lot somewhere, but I'll be darned if I can find it :/Definitely a place I need to bring my usual climbing partner, because I think she'd appreciate the route creativity :) All in all, a better gym than I thought it would be a first sight!

I started climbing in February (SuperBowl Sunday to be exact) and since PGB is 4 miles away from my pad, it's hella convenient.  Since I started, I've been averaging 2 visits a week, often times more.  It's definitely WAY smaller than Sunnyvale (haven't been to SF...yet!) but I love the peeps here - the staff has always been super nice and they are extremely safety oriented.  (I notice that the bad reviews I skimmed are largely due to being told they couldn't teach their friends how to belay and tie in...it's a liability issue of course, there are signs everywhere stating that only staff is allowed to coach and instruct, which makes perfect sense to me!)  Again I'm a new climber so I don't know how frequently routes are changed at other facilities but there are new ones set pretty often.I've brought an experienced climber here for a climbing date a couple times and he was impressed with both the routes and the features of the walls - lots of interesting cracks and crannies on the back wall and the slab to work with.I also love the community feel here.  People are very friendly and open. There are regular parties & events - I especially enjoy Swingles night (2nd Thursday of each month) where you get an opportunity to meet new belay partners and dine on Round Table Pizza (Win!).  I belong to two other fitness clubs so have only used the cardio equipment a couple times and have yet to go to the classes, but trying the yoga classes is definitely on my to do list.I used to go to the movies here as a kid way back when the building was the Belmont Cinema.  Love that they kept the sign (wish it lit up though - I asked about that and they said it doesn't work anymore, rats!) and some of the old movie seats.  I also think the bathroom toilet area has the original stalls and fixtures (hey as long as they work and there's ample TP...).  The locker rooms aren't Equinox quality, but then again I'm not paying Equinox prices, and they are clean and tidy.PG is also the best deal I've seen for a fitness club membership - $75 a month and that gets you into all three facilities, includes the yoga/fitness classes and free guest passes every other month as well as the first Friday of each month.  That my friends is a SMOKING hot deal!Doesn't have its own parking lot, but there's ample free parking the next block over in the Bel-Mateo section.  I've never had a problem finding a spot.The SV PG might be way bigger but PGB is my home climbing club!

Stand-out: Best vibes of all the PG'sStand-down: Stuck on dubstep :/ ... sometimes I like a chillax climbing dayTry: Climbs set by Mike A (smiley face guy) and don't be ashamed when you can't figure out his 11a's. They're special.Haterade (bathroom reviewers): No, the bathrooms aren't incredible. But would you rather them spend money on new holds / pay their rad people good wages... or a dyson hand-dryer?Qualifications: Home gym
this [lace is awesome. Great place to workout and socialize. the climbing was fantastic. Nice family friendly place and classed for all ages

ON BELAY!!!I absolutely love this place.  After work the crew usually goes here, and I have been the latest addition the last few weeks.  Tonight I decided to buy a membership with my boyfriend.  Such a great investment.  Great prices.  The only complaint I have is that I still have to rent shoes (and that is my fault.. I haven't bought ones yet).  As I type this, my hands and forearms are sore, and I love it that way.  I am now looking forward to becoming certified in belay and the ropes course!Now that I have a membership I can take all the yoga I want, boulder and climb after work, and even use the gym upstairs. It is never too crowded, so I always get a nice space to climb without feeling like someone is going to fall on me or invade my space.The staff is very friendly and helpful and the place is pretty clean.  Definitely 5 stars.  Just wish it was a little bigger like the Sunnyvale version!!

This review is only for  the gym part of the establishment not the rock climbing - I will make this fairly short and sweet.Great staff super friendly and laid back Below average equipment especially the cardio machines - treadmills out of order allot one day I went in and I believe 4 out of the 6 treadmills were out of order - same with elliptical I believe it has to do with the dust that the powder produces when people are rock climbing. Not very tidy I believe this also has to do with the powder from the RC but the yoga studio is not the cleanest eitherAll I can say is this place is good for a quick in and out work out. I believe that it is great for the RC but they are also trying to pass themselves off as a gym which does not quite work for this location. I do not know of the others but this one is a bit mediocre.

This is my usual rock climbing gym.  The people who work here are super nice compared to what the San Francisco / Sunnyvale Planet Granite.  The climbing area is smaller than the other two but I think it's at least not as crowded as Sunnyvale's on a weekday night.  (Don't make it up to SF's so don't know about that one).  I took for the 4 week climbing class which I enjoyed cuz of the tips I got in the class to help me climb, which I tell my friends when I drag them to climb with me :)If you get the membership you get to sign up friends to take their 1 hour belay class for free! (2 max at a time :))   You also get to bring in one friend for free(without the class) once every 2 months(odd months)The place does smell.. but I think most of the climbing gyms smell cuz of the shoes and sweat .  I like the routes and the climbers are friendly~

I did enjoy the rock climbing. They have you take a intro class first. Watch a 15min video, then in person you get shown how to climb and secure your harnest by one of the workers. Next visit you come in and want to climb, they will test you to see if you will get a red certified slip or a temporary slip (if you fail). Beware of the busy after work hours and weekends. Then you would have to wait for a section you are interested in climbing. This place tends to smell like feet. A lot of ppl walk around w/o shoes on. There is also a gym upstairs that has treadmills, bikes, weights, and some machines. Not too bad. I would like to thank Travis for allowing me to keep using my five day pass even after it had expired ( I'm busy and didn't check to see it had an experiation date from date of purchase, my bad).

I'm a little hesitant to post a review for this PG, because I don't want it to be over-run by all the jocks at 24 Hour Fitness. The routes are tall and varied, and the bouldering areas don't look like they ever get too crowded. The machines and weight area is nice and the equipment is in good shape. The locker rooms are also pretty clean, and the staff is super friendly.The only problem is parking around the area, but there's plenty of parking in the lot to the north of the gym.

Appears to be staffed by minimum wage teenagers.  Not very attentive.  Kids class is $70/hour, 5 kids per instructor - that means 80% of the time is spent waiting to climb.  Also that's $350/hour they are charging, for a teen instructor who they are paying $10-$15 for that hour.  What's wrong with this picture?

I have been coming to Planet Granite Belmont about twice a week for the past 3 months. This is a great climbing gym with a nice atmosphere. It is relatively small, which can make for some busy nights. The ventilation is not the greatest, even if there are a few fans around the room.The routes range from 5.3 to 5.13a (the highest I could find yesterday). Even on busy nights, I've never had to wait very long for an appropriate route.Safety is always a concern when it comes to rock climbing. I started here with the belay lesson, and I have never felt unsafe. The initial instruction was thorough and clear. Also, there is regularly a member of the staff walking around the gym and checking people belaying. On several occasions, I have witnessed them correcting people.

This has become my home gym. And it wasn't an easy thing, given that my previous home gym was 5 min drive away, and this one is 20 min away.I happened to come in for the first time the night the BRC (beginners rock climbing) class was starting, bought it on a whim and kept coming back ever since. It's a class that meets 4 times, and by the end of it I was feeling very comfortable doing whatever I wanted. Jesse and Cheyenne, the guys that taught the class, were super awesome. Some of the participants needed more help than others, and they would do whatever it takes to be helpful. Others needed a challenge, so Jesse and Cheyenne came up with the (fun) drills and harder climbs. They answered all of the questions we had, and Cheyenne even spent extra 15 minutes after the class (it ends at 9PM!!) belaying and cheering me up while I was finishing a tricky route.I live between their Sunnyvale and Belmont locations, which sort of gives me the freedom to choose between them every time I go climbing. And, even though there are more space and more routes in Sunnyvale, I prefer the Belmont location, as the staff here is so much more friendly and helpful and I truly appreciate it. They will teach you, advise you, challenge you and help you every time you need it. I also tend to bring all of my friends that want to try climbing here instead of other locations even if those are closer.As for the gym part, the machines are very simple, but there are some fun additions, like the rings and the boards. I also heard people raving about TRX classes but haven't tried them myself yet. Everything is organized nicely, and you can create a good workout using what they have. But if you are already here, you might just as well go climbing, right? Hey

I came here with reservations at 2pm to take the class so I could climb those walls. I think its a requirement if you are to start and once you complete the class, you have a temporary pass that you would bring next time where they quiz you to see if you remember. If you pass, you get a permanent pass and never have to take the class again. Also, you get a special deal at the end where it is 5 passes for $55 that is only redeemable that day you take the class. Classes are usually $20 a person so if you are into it, then you should buy it unless you get membership. The class was very thorough and lasted for over half an hour. I can imagine that it would take longer if the class was bigger but since it was only three, it was ok. I kept messing up on tying those friggin knots and I felt like I was in college again cramming right before the exam when I had to show my knots, phrases, and security checks. Dat pressure. I just wanted to climb already but the safety is important. Once you go over the actions for the climber and the belayer, then off you go to explore.It was fairly empty around 2pm but it got pretty popping closer to 3-4pm. There were classes or tours for little children so it became a zoo. So many yuppies do rock climbing and I can only imagine what the Sunnyvale and SF locations are like. You can see there are so many legit people with their chalk and shoes and it is quite intimidating but oh well. It is all about the experience and reaching the top. The routes are marked depending on difficulty. I think the easiest is 5.6 that you practice on and the hardest I saw was 5.13. The most I did was 5.9 haha. I cant help that I am short with no reach or upper body strength. Prepare yourself because your arms will hurt during and definitely the next day as I type this. You see people climbing up like spider monkeys but just take your time and if you fall, you hopefully have your partner to catch you. When you go back down, you just gotta let go and trust. It's definitely hard to let go but Frozen it up. I didnt push against the wall as I went down but I would do that or else you derp and twirl around. There are also shorter walls where you dont have a harness and a complete gym upstairs. If you are into climbing like these hardcore people, I guess this is the best option since it has your walls and a really nice gym. Go with at least one person but you wont be able to race them because one has to hold you. It is fun to go with a group of four maybe because you can cheer each other on. You dont need to bring sneakers since they provide it with your pass I think. I got the one with the class and it included everything so I think the $20 for a regular day would include equipment. Wear workout clothes like tights and a shirt since people may see up your shorts haha. The people here are really dedicated to the sport so I wouldnt worry about that actually. You will sweat as you climb and trying to reach for those things. Girls, dont forget that hair tie because it could potentially get stuck in the ropes or what not. This would totally be fun with friends and I might just do it for funsies even though I get tired so easily. I stayed for about two hours and probably only did 4 tracks haha. Good enough for me!

I don't know much about rock climbing but I do know that this place makes me want to start doing it every single day. I think they also have a gym there for people who are interested but I'd definitely recommend Planet granite for a fun time rock climbing

For those who know me personally, they know that I hate exercising. Getting me to move my old carcass around takes lots of cajoling, begging and finally, admonishing me that I need to exercise for my health.I've finally gotten around to moving my carcass around more often. The reason? It's not my health. It's so I can eat more noms.Planet Granite is crowded on weekday nights where you literally have to wait around for a route but if you go on a Monday night or even weekend it's almost empty.  Facilities are pretty clean and doesn't have the "interesting" smell that the Sunnyvale PG has.I always start out on the kiddie routes and end up somewhere on a 5.8 which for me, is a miracle. I don't have any technique per se, but it's more of a physical challenge for me that I'm using muscles that I didn't know exist. I've worked out at the gym upstairs and it's almost always empty. It's way better than Golds or 24 hour where you have to wait for machines at peak times.Trust me....if I can get my carcass to move up the wall, so can you. If you are thinking of trying it, just do it!
Don't bother to call them. They just put you on hold and never respond. Just make anther call hopefully someone else can help you right away. And there is always a competition event going on...

Planite Granite day passes are expensive, but membership is not bad for what you get.  The equipment/gear packages they sell are also a great value (harness, shoes, etc.)This location, like all others, smells like stinky feet.  It is something I had to get over, as there is no way to avoid it at these places.The staff is really awesome, and the members are pretty awesome too.  Everyone is so nice, friendly and helpful.  The locker rooms are sufficient, as are the climbing walls and and standard gym equipment.  Parking is a little tougher in this location with street parking versus the Sunnyvale location, where they have a large free parking lot.

Looking for a new hobby? Rock climbing is something you should try. Great place to work your upper body and legs. Very nice staff and they make sure you know how to belay / use their equipment.Definitely coming back, good music too. Probably need more fans or windows, too many people can cause the place to smell a bit funky at times but overall good. They also have other locations and once you are in their system you are good.

Had my daughter's 10th birthday party here. Girls had a great time, there are areas to climb for someone who is just a beginner to one with more advanced skills. 4 to 1 kid to instructor ratio was good (their maximum is 6 to 1). Everyone, from people at the front desk to instructors were super nice and accommodating. Special thank you to Jesse who handled the arrangements and was there on hand to answer all questions and make sure that everyone was having a great time. If you're thinking of a birthday party or to just come a climb I would highly recommend this place.

Love this place in the morning for lifting because no one plays with the weights other than 3 people. The classes they have to offer in the AM are tough and led by this lady with a drill sergeant attitude .  The climbs here feel more challenging compared to Sunnyvale and SF even though it might be the same grading. I took my lead test here and they are accommodating vs the busy San Francisco gym and Sunnyvale gym at peak hours. Friendly environment for all are and skill levels.

On belay?  Belay on!!New to climbing?  Expert climber?  Looking for a great workout?..... Then this is the perfect place to be.  PG offers many classes for all climbing levels.  I took a class here when I first started climbing and the staff made it a really fun and safe experience.  Although this climbing gym is pretty small (especially compared to the SF and Sunnyvale location) it's my favorite, for sure.  I like this location because the staff is way more energetic and it's always clean.  I also love getting in a cardio workout on the 2nd floor because it allows me to watch the climbers instead of staring at my treadmill screen during my entire workout.  If you've thought about climbing, this would be a great place to start... You'll feel right at home!

I originally joined Planet Granite at their Sunnyvale location, which is much larger than the Belmont location. However, we live just down the street, so Belmont has become my new home. All the staff are friendly and I see them cleaning the machines often. I wish they had better ventilation, at times especially in the summer months it can get a bit stinky. Also, some of their classes take place in between the main work out areas which can also be frustrating (especially when they take all the mats and weights). Perhaps they will have people start bringing their own mats to participate, which would be a plus.I also hope they start offering their pilates classes on other days than Sunday. I'd love to go during the weekday when I have the time! I wish they also had the "gym only" option  again which was a bit cheaper since my belay partner is injured for the foreseeable future and we aren't utilizing the rock climbing aspect.
My go to gym. My hubby loves to climb so I tag along. People are nice and routes are challenging. If i need nick pick on something is that the place should has some heating!

Planet Granite is a great climbing gym, however this location (when compared to the other two) is a little bit on the weak side. It's not bad at all, but I mean it's just sort of small. The top roping routes are pretty short and it can get crowded really fast due to the smaller space of this location. The staff is kind and the other members are great too. There are two bouldering chambers around the outside as well as a yoga room. There is a fitness center upstairs and I believe this location allows for you to just have a fitness membership at a cheaper price than the 70 bucks a month for the full gym access. Not bad I thought.

This was my first experience rock climbing. Conclusion, I am very bad at it. That's not to say I can't climb. I can climb. Despite my small, unassuming frame... I'm quite quick and agile. The height of the climb wasn't really an issue either. Truthfully, I thought the height was exciting. I suck at it because apparently, I am really bad at multi-tasking. Who knew? We started with the belay lesson. Our instructor was great. I think his name was Brandon? Anyway, we found him to be fun and informative. He went over different types of knots that we would be using. Figure eight, double figure eight, double fisherman's knot, etc. I soon discovered that there's more to climbing than just climbing. Many steps to memorize and be proficient at.You must be able to:- attach the belay device- complete a safety check for the belayer (check harness, check that you are clipped into your harness, check that the carabiner is locked, check that the belay device is fed and configured properly)- tie in with a double figure eight knot, followed by a double fisherman's knot- do a safety check on the climber (check harness, check where the rope is tied into, check figure eight knot, check double fisherman's knot)- demonstrate correct communication (climber says, "on belay." belayer says, "belay on." climber says, "climbing." belayer says, "climb on.")- demonstrate correct belay techniqueI went first. I got all the way to the top without incident. Rang the bell to signal success. Then suddenly realized, I had no idea how to come down. So, I call down to my instructor, "Okay, now what?" Probably something I should have inquired about prior to. He responded with something like, "Just sit back as if you are in a seated position. Grab the rope with two hands and let your partner do the rest." Easy enough, if you aren't a control freak like I am. Needless to say, my partner came through for me.  Now it was the bf's turn. No fair. He'd been rock climbing before, so some of what we were expected to know, he'd already practiced. He too reached the top without incident. I then suddenly had a thought. Oh, s**t! Is the obvious difference ie; his height/weight ratio to mine going to be a problem?! He's 6' 5". I'm 5' 1". He clearly significantly outweighs me. What's going to happen when I release the brake?! I turn to my instructor with my concerns. He assures me I should be fine. I release the brake... and... F**K! The weight of my partner starts to pull me!!! I calmly blurt out a few profanities while informing my instructor of what is taking place. He quickly grabs ahold of the rope and we (together) safely lower my partner to the ground. What I learned from my 1st climbing experience:- I love to rock climb- I could benefit from much more additional instruction- I am not-so great with the multi-tasking- Watermelon weights (they aren't REALLY watermelons, but instead weights that you attach to your harness to keep you grounded) are a must for petite climbers like myself who climb with larger partnersPlanet Granite is a great place to climb, especially in the mornings. Perfectly set routes for all levels. Tons of routes to figure out. You could climb non-stop for hours and never even come close to trying everything in your level. And... if the dates on the cards are any indication, the routes change quite frequently. Enough to challenge the most experienced climbers.The front desk staff members were all very friendly and attentive. I'll likely be back, as I'm considering taking the B.R.C. course... if they ever offer it on a Monday or a Tuesday (my days off). For now, the course is only offered Wednesdays from 7-9pm. I only wish that I lived closer so I could come here everyday.

I went here for Valentine's Day with my husband. We were completely new to everything, so we took a short 30min beginners class.
