For just 30 bucks per person they gave you rental shoes, the class and as long as we wanted to climb for the rest of the day. I had a great time. The only thing I would recommend it to buy your own shoes. The rental shoes they gave me really smells (duh since they are rental shoes) and also it was not an exact fit (apprent

If you're an experienced climber, leave all your experience and habits outside. Planet Granite is so anal on how they run their place that they will harp on you if they don't have it their way. I was scolded at for trying to give a climbing refresher course to my partner. I was told my partner had to take a class to learn to belay and set the figure 8.  My fault for actually knowing how to really climb and teach... Also, the day pass price to outrageous!! $20 is a bit too much for the amount of routes and size of the gym. I pay the same price at planet granite in Sunnyvale and SF for twice the routes and size. On top of that, it's over crowded. I drove in traffic from SF to be in traffic waiting for a route to open. Your paying $20 to literally wait for open routes.Overall, not a bad climbing gym if your a beginner. For the experienced climber, I recommend going to planet granite in Sunnyvale or San Francisco.

Murphys law. When you plan and everything goes wrong. Well, that was the case for my guest. I'm a member here and I'm hesitant to write a review. Why you ask?  Its cause its awesome and I don't want to share!   Well, after today, I would feel horrible not sharing. I signed a gf for a belay class and she ended up being super late.  Well, poor girl had a few bad things happen which caused her to be an hour late. The instructor told me he would wait and sure enough, he did.  This isn't the first time its happened (different guest)  Every time I come here,  the staff is always friendly.  They make one feel comfortable and ts awesome.  One day,  I came in and it was packed. I came in with someone who had a day pass. It was so busy, we decided to leave less than an hour later. The gal at the counter gave him a pass for another day to make up for that one.   Can't say enough good things about the service. I'm definitely sticking around for a while. Yay planet granite!

First, I don't come here for the rock climbing (I don't do that...yet).  I come here for the machines and the yoga classes.Machines are always clean and functional.  I've never had to wait for one, either -- even when busy, most people are climbing, leaving the exercise machines mostly unused.  Awesome!The yoga room is nice, although it smells of feet by the end of the day.  I go to Edwina's "Foundations of Flow" class, and it's a great way to get a simultaneous workout *and* stretching that I can feel for a couple days afterwards.  She's absolutely great.  If your schedule lets you attend one of her several yoga classes, you should DO IT.The front desk staff is a little out there and occasionally maybe-stoned.  If there isn't a button to click on the front desk computer, they don't know how to do it and need to call a manager.  Eh, what can you expect from today's college kids? :-)

Free fun is gooood, like 5 star goood.  If you know a member here, the first Friday of every odd number month entitles them to bring a guest.  As a first timer, you get belaying/climbing lessons as well as equipment for free.I've never climbed before, hell the last time I even tried anything remotely similar was long ago when I failed climbing a tree for my 5th grade crush MaryLou, so I approached this with a lot of trepidation.The lessons were informative, and quite comprehensive on the safety aspects of tying knots and belaying, though could be more thorough in the actually execution of the climb.  I guess I really shouldn't kick out when coming down, huh?  I picked a climb that was in a corner and ended up cartoon bouncing back between the two walls smashing into the AC vent before finally getting down...so a bit banged & bruised.But if you can swing this w/ a current member, you're saving like $40...not bad if you bored on a Fri night.On a side note, for my fellow bigfoots, they only have up to size 14's on rental and they are sized down by 1/2.

Silicon Valley yuppies ditch their suits and dresses and the monotony of the 9am-5pm work schedule to become super hero climbers at Planet Granite.THIS IS WHERE ALL THE YOUNG PEOPLE ARE.  On a weeknight, PG is flooded with 20 and 30-somethings -- I just fit right in.  Climbing has become an incredible stress relief outlet and a healthy hobby!  No wonder it caught on so well.I started off as a young grasshopper of a climber.  I am by NO MEANS a natural at rock climbing.  I can't position my body well, the lack of dexterity in my fingers is largely unhelpful, and I have little arm strength to contribute.  But man, oh man.  After one month (2 climbing sessions/week), I improved leaps and bounds.  PG has plenty of courses and you can always find a challenge.  The Belay Course:  1 hour course, offered at 6, 7, 8pm on most days.  First, you learn how to tie-in, learning the knots, the safety check system.  Next, you learn how to belay: hook-in, safety checks, feed the rope, and brake.  My friend and I were the only ones in this course so we received personal attention.  The instructor had a bit of trouble accommodating for a lefty (myself), but it was a-ok.The Belay test:  line up!  It's a lightning fast hands-on quiz of everything you learned in the belay course.  Don't flinch or you may not pass.  :O  No pressure though.  Just refresh the basics and you'll earn the red belay certification in no time!The top-rope climbs:  there are so many!  Varying heights, difficulties, and features.  The courses are altered monthly.TIPS for 1st timers:- It's gonna be a blast. - If possible, I recommend you eat a light dinner beforehand so you have some energy to devote to those muscles.  Or bring a Cliff bar (ya know, cuz you'll be hanging off cliffs?).  - I don't recommend that you wear shorts just bc it may result in an embarrassing wedgie.- Find solace in the steam room.  10 minutes and your muscles will thank you.- The parking lot gets pretty full just FYI.  It's unavoidable.Overall, after one month of climbing, I'm hooked.  After one and a half months of not climbing, I vow I will return soon.  The people here are incredibly inspirational and I can only strive to do what they can do!  No complaints.  :)

***Good***Decent selection of top-roping routes. Average workout facilities. Solid cardio setup. ***Bad***Bouldering here isn't very fun. Not a great set-up or selection of routes. ***Recommendation***Go to the PG in SF
This place is great! Very helpful staffs, interesting paths, and not a lot of people. The only problem I have is the men's bathroom is kinda stinky.
Great place. Wonderful service, the staff is friendly. Good for kids 5 star.

slowly edging PG-SF in the music category.sorry Patty.especially mid-day when the place is 99% empty.also, the locker rooms, saunas, showers with tons of towels, shampoo, conditioner, bd wash, are awesome. (I've heard the womens was a bit cramped so the guys definitely lucked out)

$20.00 for the daily pass:   $17.00 to climb and boulder.  $3.00 for the harness.    I saved a few bucks because I brought my own climbing shoes and caulk.My friends and I visited Planet Granite last Saturday.    My goal was to utilize all the strength I worked on for the month of March and put it to the test at bouldering.    The simple and intricate patterns (steps) are mind blogging but worth every minute during my climb and canvassing.       It wasn't very crowded on a early Saturday morning so I was able to take my time and scale the walls with ease.   No one bothered me and I didn't feel rushed.     I was able to sort out the difficult ones and improvise well.By late morning, a group of kids (5-8 year olds) began to flood one of the bouldering rooms. That's when I decided to call it quits.  Besides my hands began to blister up after two hours of workout.There is workout gym upstairs and a yoga room downstairs next to the lobby.  I didn't venture upstairs but I did see eliptical machines.   The lobby has a gift shop and appearal station (in case you want to get into indoor rock climbing or bouldering).   I will be visiting again for another strength test.

I am here pretty much every week so I guess its about time I wrote a review.  I have not actually been to the other PG locations yet so I cannot compare, but I will compare to Rockreation, my old gym in LA.  The top rope routes here are fantastic.  They set new routes just frequently enough that I have a new challenge once I have tried most of the routes at my level.  The gym does get pretty crowded on weeknights after about 7:30 so the earlier you go, the better.  It does get to the point where I am waiting for ropes.I don't like the bouldering areas quite as much as my previous gym.  It seems that they are all just incredibly challenging so it is difficult to get started if you aren't already an expert climber.  I was able to do most V0 and V1 routes at my last gym, but I can barely handle the V0s here.  Just a little frustrating.The amenities are great.  There are regular yoga and kickboxing classes and lots of cardio equipment.  And even a sauna in the locker room!  Overall a really great gym.

This is possibly the best gym in the Peninsula. They have a small free weight area, which is separate from all of the machines and abs section, and it is never crowded! They also have great rock climbing and fantastic route setters. The staff is extremely nice and approachable. The gym is constantly being cleaned and it seems new routes are being added. You also don't get the highschools kids in here that take up machines and free weight but spend 45 min. starring at themselves and flexing. Overall this gym has a great crowd, a great set up, a great staff, 5 stars because it is perfect.

Went for some bouldering. I've been training my grip for the last couple months and it was still incredibly challenging. When my hands got tired, I headed up to the gym for some running and lifting. Everything was great. Two bouldering rooms with a variety of challenges. Chill people and good equipment.

I love that this Planet Granite is not only a climbing gym, but also has yoga and regular workout equipment.  I love that this Planet Granite is less than 5 minutes drive away from my house.I don't like that the membership is $70+ a month.  But they do have a sauna which can be a nice benefit I have yet to use.I wish there was a easier way to find climbing partners. I wrote my name on the board but still no one has emailed me. :(  Now that I am a member, I need to go more often!

A smaller gym that offers all the climbing amenities- sweet routes, friendly faces, nice locker rooms, fitness center, and yoga/workout classes. The staff and climbers here are super friendly, and the overall vibe is down to earth like a good homie! Perhaps one of the greatest parts of this gym is the pushing limits class where you can get personalized advanced lead techniques, feedback and instruction from experienced climbers Stephanie and the belmont manager, Dan. Really great people and teachers- this class has given the tools I need to become a stronger and more confident climber!

Planet Granite (PG) is a rock climbing gym, fitness club and yoga studio all wrapped into one nice (and economical) package.  Twice a year, in winter and summer, PG offeres a no initiation fee membership sign-up period.  As I recall, the period typically lasts a few weeks.I've been a PG member for about three years now.  I've made extensive use of their exercise equipment and have taken several rock climbing classes there.  I don't really have anything negative to say other than that I have occasionally found the front desk staff to be less-than-attentive and sometimes unfriendly but for the most part, they're pretty good.The upkeep at PG is outstanding.  The locker rooms are clean and well-stocked and the exercise and climbing equipment are well-maintained and CLEAN.  Membership prices are reasonable (around $64/mo for singles).  The climbing routes range anywhere from beginner to expert, with lots in between for intermediate climbers like me.Things you should know:- You don't have to be a rock climber to join PG -- they have a "fitness-only" membership option which costs less than the fitness+climbing one.- Do not park in the tire store parking lot just south of PG -- you will be towed.  Instead, park one block north on the same side of the street.- Weekend afternoons are very popular for kids' birthday parties, so if you don't like kids or birthdays or parties, stay away.- PG gets crowded around 7PM during the week.  Even when it's crowded, there should always be a route available for climbing.- PG does not have a swimming pool.

I had my daughter's 10th birthday party here last week and it was a great experience.  The staff was extremely helpful and very nice.  They attended to our every need and were so kind.  The place is very clean and well kept.  This is a great fun place to have a birthday party.  I highly recommend it.

While I do agree that this location is much smaller than Sunnyvale, to me it's a blessing!  Belmont is NEVER packed, meaning less downtime while climbing.  The staff and fellow patrons are a lot friendlier and the overall feel is more laid back.  If you're looking for a great place to go climb and meet some friendly faces while you're at it, this is the place!  The only downfall is that they offer less yoga classes than the other locations.

Like the gym, but it's a smaller facility than their San Francisco counterpart and what's up with all the Rap music?  How do you climb to that?  Would be good if the music was more generic for everyone to enjoy/tolerate.  :)

I've been a member here for about 3 months now. I agree with many of the positive comments and reviews about this place. It is clean, the staff are generally friendly, the equipment is in pretty good shape. I don't climb I'm just there for the work out so I use the weights and take some classes. Edwina's Saturday morning yoga class is great. I've never taken a yoga class before in my life and she has me totally hooked. So why the 3 stars? Dealing with getting my automatic payment set up was a pretty big pain in the butt. They won't accept a credit or debit card.  You *must* give them a voided check. There is absolutely no other option possible. What year is this people? I don't have checks. I pay my bills through automatic bill pay like other people who live in this century. So I took their little form to my bank and the teller filled out all the correct information for them. THIS was not enough. They said because it wasn't printed on bank stationary it was not acceptable. I asked them to call the bank and verify the routing number and account information. They said "most banks won't do that".  I told them that my bank told me they would gladly do that and they said they could not help me. My only option was to bring them a voided check or pay for 3 months in advance with my debit card. This is just laziness on the part of the accounting people there. I ended up having my bank specially make a check for me just to give to Planet Granite. (see my very positive review of them!) I almost had to drop my membership because of this because I don't want to pay 3 months in advance. If my bank had not been so helpful I would have dropped my membership. It really is sad because this is a great gym. I have consistently had nothing but great customer service from the staff. It is a really good price for what you get out of this membership. Edwina is awesome. While I'm not a climber it is fun to watch all the kids climbing up the walls while I ride the bike or run on the treadmill. It looks like fun and it appears the instructors are really engaged with people. If the people in the office were willing to work with customers and consider that there is more than one way of doing things I would gladly give this place 5 stars.

I had a wonderful experience learning to climb here, marred only slightly by the very cranky staff member who did my belay exam on my second visit. I did not use the technical terms for the knots (which I made correctly) and she told me to re-test next time... uhh, really? Note to self: do not request a belay exam before lunch!My lesson was taught by a staff member who was patient and thorough. The gym accommodates a variety of levels, though there are very few climbs available for the very beginnerest of beginners (but luckily I didn't stay that way for long!). It's a bit expensive ($19 for a drop in, plus $6 equipment), but frequent groupons and multi-passes make it a bit easier on the wallet. Note: there is no heat or AC! Note 2: this gym also offers yoga and the standard cardio equipment (but I have no experience with those!)

Music volume level needs to be regulated by management.About half the time it is too loud and I wind up asking them to turn it down.Please just put a mark on the dial and keep it there. It's not only annoying for those of working out to not be able to hear our own music players; it's possibly a hazard for the climbing partners who can't hear belay instructions.

Oh my gawd! It is freezing in here!!!I bought a Groupon for 2 and used it as a date night for the boyfriend and myself. We came in late Thursday evening and the person at the front said the classes were completely filled. Huh? There's classes? I didn't even know that we should have called in advance to reserve. Wish they would have noted that on the Groupon. Luckily we didn't drive that far to Belmont and we were free the following evening. I want to take a star off, but coming back the next night for the class, we met an extremely cool instructor that added that star back on. Andres was chill and completely put someone like me that is afraid of heights, at ease. I would highly recommend him. The steps to tie knots and make sure you know the safety calls/precautions, I felt like a pro after the hour class. I was belaying my boyfriend on a 5 10 wall on my own by the end of the night.I would totally come again and take the belay test!!! Highly recommended for date night. It's a great team exercise and made us both communicate and work well together! I placed a lot of trust in my partner and he did the same for me. Thanks Andres for the encouragement!!! We hope to see you again real soon!

Belmont is the smaller Planet Granite sibling in the South Bay. The gym was converted from an old movie theater and true to the old place the gym keeps a few theater seats as a good memory of it. I'm really impressed with Planet Granite because I can expect the same quality in both gyms. The routes are fun and Belmont also provides good bouldering routes. I find myself frequenting this place during the week because less crowded than Sunnyvale. Also, if you like sandwiches Ike's Lair is a close drive by and pick up for a post-climbing meal.

I had never climbed before, but I am generally quite athletic (professional fencing coach).  I did the BRC (beginning rock climbing class) here and had a great time.  It was like 125 for rental stuff for the 4 classes, and membership for the gym for the month of the class.  Instruction in the class itself was mediocre.  Not a whole lot of actual help being given, but the price of the class was low enough I didn't mind.  Membership for a month is normally 70, so the class was really 55, and including rental stuff thats included, the "price" of the class is really like 25 total.After the class, I joined the gym with no initiation fee.  $70 a month seems very reasonable for the product.  Gym is overall clean.  Not full of meatheads like many gyms.  Full fitness and weights area, as well as lots of climbing routes and bouldering.Routes are changed regularly.  Good mix of grades.  A few easier than 5.8, but mainly its between 5.8 and 5.12a.  I climb 5.10c now, and any given day, there are ALOT of routes to choose from in my skill level.Big focus on safety with the grigris.  Ropes and clips all seem to be in very good shape.  Bouldering caves are nice, although I like roped climbing more.  Overall experience:  A

Love this place! PGBL may be the least crowded of the 3 PG locations in the bay area. The staff members are extremely friendly and helpful. I also took an Intro to Lead class here, it ended up being a 2-person group class, and the teacher was amazing. We got a lot of practice in too.Overall the climbs are great, with variations of long routes, overhangs, caves etc. They switch them up pretty often too.

This is my only experience with indoor rock climbing and climbing gyms, but I've taken climbing classes and climbed outdoors before. Also, I have not used any of the facilities here other than the rock climbing section, so this applies only to that part of the gym, not the yoga, sauna, cardio equipment, etc.The number and variety of climbs here is staggering - everything from 5.2 (super beginner) to 5.15 (superhuman), and the center section is high enough that you can actually climb for quite a while before reaching the top. You're not done in five minutes. I'm not in the superhuman category, but the challenging climbs seem to be pretty challenging, with a lot of opportunities to do lead climbing, cracks, overhangs, etc. There are also two free climbing rooms, again with routes of varying difficulty and pretty challenging holds. My one criticism is that there are only a few very basic (5.2-5.5) climbs, so if you've come with kids, or if you're just learning yourself, you may end up waiting for a while between climbs while other people climb, especially on busy weekend days.I've only taken the belay course, but the instructor was good. He knew his stuff, explained it very clearly, gave us plenty of practice, etc. Everyone of the staff has been helpful, pleasant, and knowledgeable without fail. Prices seem reasonable, but again I don't have anything to compare to - harness rental is free if you are only belaying, belay course is $34, kids day pass is $10 + $6 for harness and shoe rental = $16 bucks to climb with your kid as long as you want - even all day. Sure beats a movie!

I haven't been to PG SF but compared to PG Sunnyvale, I prefer this place. It's a lot less crowded during week days, and weekends as well. Therefore, less smelliness. OMG, the smell at PG Sunnyvale just hits you like a brick in the face every time you walk in the front door. The routes are more interesting here. Or at least that's what I find. They are technically more challenging.  I find the people who come here are also nicer than the crowd at Sunnyvale. Less cocky. And less shirt-less guys. I like guys who keep their shirts on in public, especially when their bodies are not exactly Brad Pitt's.The only thing I don't like about this place is it has only one water fountain downstairs. And the women bathroom is set up in a way that you have to walk all the way to the back to wash your hands. Not convenient, but no biggie.

We signed up and then decided to check out each location in 3 days.  It's smaller than the other 2 and I would equate it with the Great Western Power Company in terms of size, exercise equipment and climbs.  It's small and has a large cardio area upstairs which I appreciate but since I was here to climb, I didn't explore it too much.It  is not very well ventilated because none of the walls open up to let the air in and the fans were not on at first.  It was cramped and fairly cavelike but like the other facilities, the location is clean and the locker rooms are decent.It's not a bad place to climb but not my favorite.

A paradise for rock climbers and fitness enthusiasts, this gym has it all - 60 foot walls of all varying difficulty, Crossfit workout equipment, gymnast loops, rock climbing training equipment, yoga & fitness classes, bouldering walls, and a tightrope in the back. Sometimes I wish this place was open until 1 am, since I'm always here until it closes. The staff are super friendly and are open to any questions about rock climbing. I'd recommend this place to any newbie or veteran alike.

My 12 year old cousin and I were aimlessly driving around Palo Alto as I was trying to come up with something different than our usual to entertain him. Planet Granite popped into my mind, so I called to inquire about whether kids could climb (answer: yes), pricing ($10/day for those under 13) and their exact location before making the trek up El Camino. 40 minutes or so later, we arrive at Planet Granite to discover that my cousin wouldn't be able to climb without a signed waiver by one of his parents and a trained belayer, which I was not. I wish they had told me on the phone - minus one star for that.I didn't want to disappoint the little guy after the never-ending drive, so I called my uncle to complete and email the waiver to the front desk, and I desperately asked whether any of their staff would be able to belay in my stead. Thankfully, one of the workers there, Molly, made a couple phone calls and rearranged her schedule to accommodate him for a private hour-long lesson at $60. Molly did a great job of explaining the ropes and encouraging him, high-fiving him before and after each course. The hour was just enough time for him to experience walls of varying grades; he was pooped by the end. Immediately after, he decided he wanted to return for summer camp there - success!

I have been going to Planet Granite for the past one and half years and it's been great.I do have to admit that I haven't been rock climbing or bouldering as much as before because my rock climbing friends have moved out of the area. Despite the $70 per month fee, I think the price is worth it because of the yoga classes and I like having the options of going to the SF and Sunnyvale gyms, which is why I didn't downgrade my membership to fitness only for Belmont. The Belmont gym is smaller than Sunnyvale, but it's less crowded. Also the exercise/fitness area upstairs is practically empty and I have no problem getting a treadmill every time I go.When summer hits, I may not go PG as much because I prefer to run outside, but I will continue to go for the yoga/pilates classes.
Good place for rock climbing. Decent routes and good programs. Being there for a few times and enjoyed it.
Fun to do, very safe, friendly people, pricy tho

Staff is extremely friendly, and so are the other climbers!  Even when I leave my phone / wallet in the unprotected cubbies, it's never stolen.I never run out of routes to climb and I go 3-5 times a week.  $70 / month is definitely worth it!

General Facts Part of the Planet Granite Family (see more information about PG gyms in general in my PGSV review) Day passes from PGSF or PGSV from the same day will work at the other gyms.Good+ It's pretty in a converted old school movie theatre+ Has the high end equipment found in all Planet Granites+ Has good climbing+ Fun for the whole familyBad- Parking wasn't that great- Not as big as the SF or the SV facilities

The Belmont Planet Granite is really nice. I really like Planet Granite as a concept, but really didn't like their Sunnyvale gym. The smell and unhelpful staff were really terrible. Here's the pros:1. The staff at the Belmont gym are nicer2. The gym isn't as crowded3. It doesn't smell like a 5-week-old corpse4. The routes are more technically challenging I think.5. The work-out (non climbing) area is nice (much better than Sunnyvale)6. Fewer... how do I say this delicately... freaky nut jobs. There are people who climb and then there are the ear-stretchy, all-over-tatooy, stinky, shirtless, hairy, weirdos. Belmont has the former kind of climber, Sunnyvale has the latter.7. Fewer kids than Sunnyvale. I LOVE kids, don't get me wrong, but the damn parents do not watch their kids and they run EVERYWHERE just waiting to be crushed by a falling climber or tripped over.Cons:1. No parking lot - a big big con2. Towels sometimes smell funky (not unwashed, just funky)3. Mens bathroom could be cleaner.If you like climbing, you should join Planet Granite. If you want to really enjoy your climb, drive the extra distance to Belmont.

What is there to say?  It's a climbing gym and it's your only choice between San Francisco and Sunnyvale.  But the staff is friendly, the facilities are competent, and you'll have a fun time here whether your a newbie or an experienced climber.  I've been climbing here for over five years and still enjoy it.Just a couple negative points that kept it from getting five stars:  They don't update the routes as often as I would like, it gets crowded weekday evenings around 7:30, and it's not quite as high as the other PG gyms.  But those minor nits don't detract from an overall enjoyable climbing experience.

A great place to learning rock climbing! Previously, my rock climbing experience was limited to City Beach in Fremont. Planet Granite is definitely more comprehensive with people well-trained to teach you the ropes (no pun intended). My friend and I took the intro to belaying class in which they taught us how to belay and climb with a partner. This portion lasted about 20-30 mins, after which will were allowed to climb freely for the remainder of the day. Daily admission to rock climb is $17/day. Shoe rental is also available.In addition to rock climbing, there is also a gym with cardio machines and yoga classes onsite for those who have a Planet Granite membership.This would've been a 4-star review had it not been for the lack of parking in the area! How can such a large establishment not having a parking lot designated for its patrons??

This place is awesome.  I'm a total nooby I but I got myself a good workout here.  The staff is fantastic.  They are so nice and helpful.  I would definitely come more often if I can just get myself off this couch more.

I come here for the Yoga classes and all the teachers I have been to are fantastic! They are very experienced, knowledgeable, helpful and have great energy. Unfortunately, the weights seem to be right over the yoga room so you can sometimes hear people dropping weights, but I have had that same experience at most gyms.

I prefer the Sunnyvale PG location to this one.I do like that there are fewer people at this location usually, but it's starting to get more crowded.  The ventilation is much worse here and although they placed fans around, it's not quite the same.  The worse part is the bathrooms which reek!

Note: review on Ashtanga yoga classThe kind of yoga class I'm looking for. It kicked my butt so much that I was sore for 2 days afterward. Not too crowded on a Saturday AM and the instructor, despite being more like a military drill sargent, walked around the class adjusting people and shouting out poses in English and sanskrit.

When I first came to Belmont Planete Granite, I was impressed by great bouldering rooms and always interesting routes. Fun atmosphere and easy to find a climbing partner. One day I tried a free for PG members yoga class with instructor  Ben. That class was so good that eventually I started coming only for his yoga classes. What a surprise after 6 years of advanced climbing.

Though the Sunnyvale locale, with its grand, wide & tall eyefuls of all things "rockclimbing", is where this new athletic infatuation of mine took root, the smaller and modest Belmont location is where I go to nurture that passion in a less imposing atmosphere.Smaller by half the size of Sunnyvale's spacious digs, Belmont offers fewer top-rope routes but makes up for it with quite a bit of variety in "naturals(?)" (chimneys, crack, crag, slabs, etc.) and a [seemingly] more even distribution of difficulties.The same variety can be found in its two bouldering rooms (the main attraction of this gym for me); one room is primarily vertical with some overhangs while the other room offers numerous formations and severe ceiling/roof vantages... either a good testing ground for one physically and mentally.Being a smaller establishment and located in a lesser metropolitan area (the gym itself is seated aside a residential neighborhood), the fewer patrons and perchance not-so-elitist regulars contribute to a comfortable atmosphere, far less intimidating for self-conscious beginners like myself.This would be a great place to get your start or get a taste for the sport... and, shoots, drop us/me a line, maybe we'll join you...... I know what I'm doing, I promise not to drop you________________________________________And yes, somehow this location keeps itself less funktastic (BO) than its bigger, more crowded, South Bay namesake.

As rock climbing gyms go, the Belmont location of PG is just ok.  It is very small.  The routes are not very long.  There are a couple interesting "natural features" but they don't have enough routes to make this more than a once a month visit.  The other problem is that there is only street parking.  The yoga room is also very small.  With the space, they have managed to pack a lot in.  But, I prefer the Sunnyvale and San Francisco locations because there are more routes.

5 stars!  i accidentally left ALL of my rock climbing gear here about a week ago and was devastated because i would have to spend at least $100 on a new set.  Yesterday, an employee called me up and said they found EVERYTHING!  hooooray!

Rock-climbing and bouldering at its best @ Planet Granite, Belmont! For several years at Planet Granite, I rock-climbed at least 3-4 times a week (sometimes even 5 times) and loved every grueling minute of it. The staff is friendly and helpful, and it's not unusual to see the "regulars" befriending and belaying new climbers. They have great yoga classes on the first floor, and on the second floor are the weight room and the cardio area. The treadmills are facing the rock-climbers so you could get a good run in while watching someone scale a wall. The locker rooms are clean and overall, it's just a nice gym. I've climbed at the San Jose location as well but prefer Belmont's gym. Even during the day, San Jose's gym was dimly lit and kinda dark-feeling. Plus, their staff weren't as pleasant to deal with as Belmont's. Parking is easy too! There are open lots on either side of Planet Granite if you can't find something on the street.

I have been rock climbing for several years outdoors, but recently I started climbing indoors to train. I have been to all of the planet granite locations in the bay area and I like this one the best because it is the least busy day to day. All of the planet granite gyms are very clean as well, which is important incredibly important to me. The routes are challenging, the holds are new and sticky, and it is a safe environment to have fun rock climbing. This may be on the best full body workouts and you will have fun doing it! You may want to consider joining this gym as you will get access to all of the gym locations with your membership. All of the locations also have great yoga classes and they are free if you are a member.The staff at this location are friendly, helpful, and have a great attitude. This is a great idea for a date or just to go have some fun and exercise. All of the gyms are child friendly as well!
Great place, not too crowded. Usually go there on a weekend. Cons: doesn't have designated parking area, have to drive around neighborhood to look for a spot.

I'm not a rock climber seeing how I have no upper body strength. My sister is. And she's dragged me to this spot a few times. While they don't have TVs, all of the cardio machines face the rock climbing walls, so it's kind of like having a built in entertainment center. Except instead of watching reruns of the Golden Girls, you're watching people scale this ridiculous wall like Spidey. On my last visit, I even managed to take a climb myself. Pretty fun, except it's in Belmont. And I live in SF. But for you peninsula people, a fun gym with decent equipment. Rock climbing...it's the new yoga. Beware of the ball sackers (i.e. those guys that wear their straps too tightly around their man region). I almost went blind the last time I was there.

This is a cool little place.  This is the closest place to my work so my co-worker and I decided to come here and check it out.  I almost didn't even spot the place while I was driving there.  It is definitely smaller than Ironworks and I heard it's much smaller than the other PG locations.  It was nice getting a chance to see the different routes here, but I can see how it can get old pretty quickly, unless they change it up regularly.  I like the set up they have here for the little space used.  The bouldering areas are separated and away from the top rope climbing so you don't have to worry about all these people hanging above you or getting in the way of the climbers up top.This is a nice spot to stop by once in a while, but I definitely want to check out the other locations to compare.

Rock climbing is a lot of fun, but I'm not a big fan of this particular location. Maybe because I'm more used to Ironworks in Berkeley, which is significantly larger.Planet Granite didn't have enough walls for my skill level. I don't want to be climbing a latter and I can't climb the professional walls with teeny tiny rocks.Another problem I had: They use a different type of belay device than I'm accustomed to. Planet Granite uses these bulky devices which are VERY slow at lowering people down. The advantage is that they have an auto stopping mechanism, and so I assume these are safer for beginners. But it really feels like belaying for dummies!Overall, I was disappointed by my experience at Planet Granite.  If I try it again at this location, I'll bring my own equipment.
Pg Belmont, you have changed my life for the better. I am stronger and healthier bk of you. We are so lucky to have you in our community.

I came here as a guest recently and I was pleasantly surprised. I had never rock climbed before and only heard about how awesome it is through friends. Oh boy were they were right. This is a great place for beginners to go and learn the ropes and just see what it's all about. The staff was friendly and helpful overall.  I only had to pay $6 for my harness and shoes, not bad at all! I found the women's facilities clean and odor free.  I appreciate the level of difficulty and variety in the climbs. I can tell it would be hard for a novice like myself to get bored with the amount of options available. I can see now how climbing can become addicting.  I had so much fun climbing here that I would definitely come back!

I have a fitness-only membership and love it here!  Yes, the fitness area is super small (the gym is super small over all), but that just means that the grunt brothers choose other gyms.  Of course, the climbers do grunt on occasion, but that's acceptable -- I would grunt too if I were hauling my body weight solely on my fingertips.I generally go after work and it does get a little busy around 7.  That said, though, it's never difficult to get a cardio machine or to lift.The parking situation is a little bizarre (one block north on El Camino), but at least the lot is never full.

Good times, good climbs, and a good way to get off the computer. I just got home from a couple hours climbing, and I have to say, I feel great!!! The people there are fun and friendly, the staff is great, and it's a lot better than going to a bar to meet people.get out, get in shape, and have fun doing it!!

This place is really crammed and can get pretty stuffy. The bouldering is limited to small rooms. One is really dark and seems like climbing room in home basement. The top-roping walls are okay, but there are a lot of stupid who get into your way or dont' belay properly.

Luckily we live near the Sunnyvale location because this location is very small and not as challenging. Came here last night for a quick climb with my husband before meeting friends for dinner next door. Our first reaction when we walked in was "This place is SMALL!!" Plus the guy working at the front desk was kinda rude. We couldn't find the scanner gun to check in so we were roaming around looking for it and the front desk guy rudely told my husband that he couldn't go in until he got checked in....yeah we know buddy! We tried out a few climbs and this place is definitely a lot less challenging then Sunnyvale. We are still newbies at this and I climb a 5.8 and my husband climbs usually a 5.9. Those levels are still pretty challenging for us. We tried out some climbs and the first one I did was a 5.9 and I did it so easily! My husband tried a 5.10b and didn't find it challenging at all. Usually we would be dying after climbs like this. It was quiet but this is normal at the Sunnyvale location as well on a Friday night. Locker room is a lot smaller and definitely not as nice as Sunnyvale.A good alternative if you are in the area.  I feel lucky that we live near the Sunnyvale location which is A LOT better.
I LOVE PLANET GRANITE!!!Pro ShopRock ClimbingYogaCardio MachinesWeightsShowersSaunaAwesome staffGreat ratesWhat is there not to love!!

I didn't actually climb here (except for testing out the shoes on the bouldering route before I bought them), but I liked this place.  Vs. PG in Santa Clara, this spot looks like it was built to have high ceilings (and thus long routes), in order to be a climbing gym, whereas Santa Clara looks like the supernatural rock-gym-god stood in the center of a vacant warehouse, and spat out molten lava in all directions, which conformed to the shape the warehouse was already in.These guys had a really well-priced gear package of harness, shoes, and chalk/bag for $119, which is definitely better than I'd be able to pick the components up for separately...the shoes fit so I bought them.

I love Planet Granite in Belmont!   It's way, way, way less crowded than the Sunnyvale location and I think the bouldering is more challenging than the Sunnyvale location.  I meet my daly city gf here for climbing.  It's great. Oh yeah hot guys working at the counter and climbing doesn't hurt either.   Only downside is that it's $70+ a month, it isn't affordable for everyone but if you're the type who'd rather climb/yoga than drink martinis on a friday night, then it's all good.

The best climbing gym in the area, hands down.  Even better than "that gym in the mission" that everyone raves about... anyone who's been to both will expound upon the benefits of PG.  The routes are more cleanly set, the staff is FAR more helpful and friendly, the place is clean and well maintained and the yoga and fitness options are handy.  Check em out if you're nearby.  They're worth it.

I -LOVE- this place. The staff is extremely friendly, though a bit transient. They are very helpful in getting you where you need to be if you're interested in learning how to climb - indoors or outdoors!If you're interested, take the Beginner Rock Climbing course to see how you like climbing...you'll be hooked. My husband and I joined a year ago out of interest in climbing, and we made so many friends and learned about so many fun places to hike and climb outdoors as a result. Its a VERY friendly community! If my schedule allowed, I'd still be a member, but I cant make it to evening yoga classes anymore - and that was my main reason for being there - so I had to change gyms. My only complaint is that I wish they offered more yoga classes in the mornings during the week, between 8am-10am. They have great teachers, just not enough morning classes.

Good fun for all. The people working there make sure that you are safe and comfortable and trained. It's a great way to spend the better part of a day with a group of friends. It is interactive and thrilling. Everyone can aspire to the level they want without being looked upon as an amateur. Ha! I feel like I could scale Half-Dome after day one!NEW RULE: People climbing here need to wear shirts because they either stink or their pale flabbiness is unsightly!

True, Planet Granite Belmont is smaller than the other PGs in San Jose and San Francisco, but the club intime environment creates, rather than diminishes, chances for social interaction and fun. Housed in the building that once was the old Belmont Theatre, the lodges have been turned into a very well equipped weight room with Cybex and traditional free weights. There are also stations for TRX Suspension Training along with Abs and Core classes. The newly renovated bouldering cave downstairs is on a much more professional, high-standard than the old kids bouldering room that used to occupy that space previously. There is another bouldering room where easier problems can be found too. A Yoga room is adjacent to the main climbing area where there are climbs between 5.13 and easy 5.6 walkups for beginners. I personally like the sauna in the men's room for warming up first on cold days and for getting a sweat up after working out or climbing. The sauna seems to be working a lot more of the time than the one in Sunnyvale.The staff is courteous and competent and lessons are available at convenient times. So if you are a beginning, intermediate or advanced climber, I would recommend PG Belmont as an excellent venue for learning and practicing rock craft. If the main climbing wall is a little short, you'll find the overhanging boulder problems in the new cave plenty challenging.

After climbing at PG Sunnyvale for the past 6+ months, I switched over to Belmont due to my new commute up the 101.   Great climbing and work out facility, like Sunnyvale, but here are the differences.  Belmont is way less crowded; especially the bouldering area.  Sunnyvale is bigger withmore hard climbs/problems and from what I can tell generally more hard core climbers.  Sunnyvale has an outdoor area (however I sprained my ankle and f-ed up my knee out there so not a huge fan).  Belmont does not have spin classes.  Sunnyvale's fitness area has more fun apparatus (i.e. jungle gym features and ropes).  Sunnyvale has a more awesome front desk crew that will shoot the shit with you; however I may just be biased to this as this is where I started.  And Belmont's parking situation is a little odd, but that's not a big deal.    Basically Sunnyvale is little cooler, but Belmont is less crowded.  And for those in the PA area, you would be surprised how close Belmont actually is.

The appeal to this gym is the climbing. Although I like the honesty of bouldering, I am more into general fitness so I went here for the weights as well. For me, the big problem with this place is the basement like atmosphere:  small windows, it's not light well, old carpet... just kind of gloomy. Also, equipment gets misplaced or is just falling apart, and so it just feels like you are in a gym that is slowly going out of business.And, although it may sound petty, coming in the door is frequently annoying. Even if you have two people working the counter they are always preoccupied so you just stand there "hello". It got so ridiculous that I would usually just walk in without trying to register my card. If I was desperate (like this was the last gym on earth) I could make the best of it because they have a decent selection of free weights and they have the rock to climb, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone not TOTALLY into belaying.

Compared to the Sunnyvale and newly opened Crissy Field location, the Belmont PG is the least modern and nicely equipped. However, it is the only rock climbing gym in the penninsula, and also the least crowded gym of the three. The staff and the fellow climbers are always friendly.  I also enjoy the few yoga classes that I've attended. The only real problem that I have with this gym is that it is always freezing, and wearing a long sleeved shirt and sweat pants when bouldering can get pretty annoying. Yeah...you can join a fully equipped gym like equinox, prime time or save some money at the local 24 hour fitness. Sure those gyms have pools, hot tubs, and shampoo in the showers. What they don't have are the scores of young, hot guys, constantly parading their rock-climbing physiques.  Half an hour on the stair master is A LOT more enjoyable when you have a good view.
I like it.. although it smells pretty gross at times. The staff is pretty cool.

I really enjoy PG Belmont.  I thought its size would be an issues, but they have some REALLY interesting walls they've routed well and they have a great selection of books that I love looking through.  I will definitely be back to work out  on the walls here.  I very much recommend it.  The center walls are almost 50' high, so there are some fantastic challenges.  Even the shorter outer wall has some really well done routes to exercise your body and your mind.  Sometimes the solutions are more mental than physical.  There are a lot of other amenities available, but I have not made any use of them and cannot comment, but the gym looks good and the bathroom was spacious with changing areas, showers, and a sauna, I believe.  Again, did not personally check out a lot of those amenities, just know that when I want to work on my climbing, PG Belmont has what it takes to make me sweat.

Despite being smaller, this lacks the hominess of PG Sunnyvale. The parking is downright sucky, the staff are kinda holed up at the front desk which is separate from all the facilities, not like PG sunnyvale where you can shoot the sh*t with folk in between routes. However, the peeps seem to all know each other and be friendly. That's a good thing.
Great rainy day activity.  They have climbing walls at various difficulties.  Something there for all ages.  My kids love it too!

I love this place.  I consider myself an amateur climber but I feel like there are many walls here that I can climb with ease.  There are also many walls that are very difficult and I love that challenge.  They have 2 great little bouldering rooms to warm up on, and the main room is usually not that crowded.  Price is very fair and they even have the option to get a gym membership there that includes climbing. (yes they have a gym here as well).  Locker rooms are very clean along with the whole building.  Definitely nicer than most climbing places I have been to! Highly recommend!

Love it here!  I am fairly new to climbing.  They have a wide range of levels and will keep you busy for a long time trying to get good at all of them. We just got a membership here that covers climbing, yoga and other classes, full gym, and sauna at both the Belmont and Sunnyvale locations. All their fitness equipment is in great shape.  I haven't taken any of their classes yet but will be trying their new Ab routine soon!  The Sunnyvale location is larger with more places to hide from large groups of kids.  To avoid kiddy parties, try early weekend mornings and Friday night.

Belay On!Super nice staff, smaller climbing gym but it wasn't over crowded (was here Sunday afternoon) there was also bouldering, a fitness  area and yoga.  Not sure what the cost was, my date had a guest pass (great idea guys....prefect setting to get to know someone!). I will definitely come back if I am in the area...maybe after riding Waterdog... Oh and the girls locker room had a sauna...NICE!Parking is a little weird though.

The Belmont PG is smaller, with fewer people -- which is why I love it. In general, PG has been useful since for a $70 per mo membership, you get unlimited access to climbing, the gym, and classes. (They just increased to $73)BOULDERINGIt has 2 great bouldering rooms, one only for over 14 years old.  There's never a wait for bouldering or ropes.  There are frequently kids' parties on weekends, which can be cute or annoying depending on your leaning.CLASSESHarriet's circuit class MWF mornings are fun, and not too busy.  The yoga classes are good - Doris' class is popular. STAFFThe staff at PG Belmont are also well-knowledged in climbing, nice, approachable, and helpful.  In general, all of the climbers at the gym are quite nice, a bit of an older crowd than Sunnyvale, regulars and willing to help if needed.PG Sunnyvale is larger, but much busier - one night I couldn't even find a free rope!  And another night it was so crowded that the body funk forced me out.  More open bouldering (so people are watching - not great for a beginner).PG Belmont is super quiet/empty in the morning/daytime, but fills up a bit more in the evenings.

If you like to get high, this is the place for you (as long as you can drag your ass up the big walls and not fall down).  You should also get rid of that spare tire, which you can do at Planet Granite before or while you are working to concur the various top down walls and two (yes two) separate bouldering rooms.  What that mean is when an asshole brings his 4 year old that plays consistently on the bouldering mats, you can go to the other room (before you do, say hi because that asshole is me).Planet Granite has a grigri setup for you at every top down climbing route, so you can leave your ATC at home (or carry is around for no reason, like me [the asshole]).  The routes vary nicely, from a almost vertical 5.2 to several extra tall LEAD routes.  As I said earlier, I take my son with me and PG supplies good quality shoes and harnesses for all ages.Best part, if you have your belay lesson at PG you get a 1/2 off day pass.

I was never a big fan of any gym especially given the close quarter/smell. I don't climb but I like the yoga lessons here. They aren't as hardcore thus are perfect for newbies like myself. The lessons are also more affordable compare to a going to a yoga studio. The friendly staff doesn't hurt.

As a drop in visitor I love when people make you feel as important as a member and Planet Granite did just that.  Their yoga room is super nice but not quite sound proof so you do get some noise from the climbing area.  I really enjoyed the yoga class here!  Very welcoming and good for any level.  I love it when you go to a gym and everyone is friendly.  My brother and sister-in-law love the climbing space.  Overall a pretty cool gym.

Ok. I've been here ONCE. I'm not an expert climber by any stretch of the imagination, but I do enjoy it, and go about once or twice a year. WTF is up with their rental harnesses??! NOT a fan. While they're safe enough, the straps don't double back, and loosened when I stood up. That made me DEEPly uncomfortable. But they must know what they're doing. Once I got up there, my weight made sure those straps were nice and tight, and didn't budge. But I have to say... it doesn't help calm you down when your harness isn't to standard specs. Come on. Other than that, I loved this place. There are plenty of climbs for all levels. Everything is well labeled, and the staff was great. I'll definitely be back. But I will bring my own harness this time. Yikes.

Just had my first belay lesson here this past week.  The Belmont location has plenty of space, climbs with a variety of difficulty levels, and even a gym upstairs.  Our instructor, Peter, gave us a thorough rundown of all the basic safety checks, procedures, and call-outs.  After your lesson, they give you a snipet of rope to practice for your test and a pass to climb for the rest of the day.  This was totally a great experience -- you really get your heart pumping and this huge sense of accomplishment when you reach the top of that 50-foot wall!

Woohoo!  Another Planet Granite.  This place is great considering that it's closer to San Francisco than the Planet Granite in Sunnyvale.  It's true that it is smaller compared to the one in Sunnyvale, but it has two floors!  The bottom floor contains two bouldering caves, a top-roping area and a yoga room.  The second floor contains a weight area, treadmills and a fitness room.  The restrooms have a sauna and locker area as well.The routes here are fun, but not as fun as the ones found in the Sunnyvale gym.  The great thing about this gym is that it isn't as crowded as the Sunnyvale location.  The prices for rentals and one day passes are on the website and there are student discounts as well.  If it's your first time climbing, I suggest scheduling a belay class with a friend.Definitely a friendly and chill environment.  Come here and have a good time!

I still like the place but they raised their rates again a few months ago so I bought a couple 10 packs for the classes and canceled my membership.There was really only one class I was attending with any regularity especially since Nandi Yoga opened in San Mateo.As soon as my second 10 pack is finished I will not return to PG.  Even their 10 pack and single classes is a lot more expensive than the competition.I like PG but I think they are a lot more expensive than the competition.  I pay 29 USD a month for Golds and have acess to RWC and SM where each has three rooms of classes at any given moment.  PG is 53 a month for fitness only.As far as yoga PG chages 17 USD for a drop in and 160 USD for a 10 pack.  Nandi yoga charges 16 USD for a drop in and 14 USD (for seniors and students) and 130 USD for a 10 pass.

I fell in love wtih rock climbing and joined Planet Granite about a year and a half ago.  I have to say, it just doesn't get any better than this.The staff are friendly, playful and knowledgeable.  The other customers are helpful and work like a community.  They'll give you advice if you want it, or encouragement if you don't want advice.  They'll chat with you while you're belaying.  The rates are about the same as any other climbing gym, but there's no contract to sign here - which is nice.  You can go month to month, and if you're going on vacation or if you get injured, you can put your account on hold for a month.The Belmont location is relatively small, but with some great bouldering opportunities.

Planet Granite's Belmont location is the oldest in the chain and it shows at times - the other locations, San Francisco and Sunnyvale, are nicer, even in spite of a much-needed recent upgrade to Belmont's fitness equipment and climbing area floors (thank you).  Membership gets you entry to all three locations though.    Other observations:The men's restroom smells really bad.  I cannot be the only one who notices this because my nose generally doesn't work very well.  I don't know what the problem is there - it has been that way from day one (I joined when the gym opened).  I know the staff cleans it regularly, so it must either be an issue with the plumbing or users not flushing, but both are things that can and should be addressed.The men's shower is communal, no stalls.  It doesn't get used much.  I hear the women's locker room is better on both counts.    The roof leaks every winter.   The staff tries to catch the water in myriad buckets on heavy days.  I think the water soaking into the foam floor causes it to have a musty or moldy smell.  A new floor has been installed this year though, so that will help, but the roof still leaks.  It's taking forever for them to fix two of the four spin bikes that are broken upstairs, but that may not be their fault.  Climbing and classes are fun - that's really why most people (including me) come here.  The space is still smaller than SF or SV, but still a reasonable variety.  I agree with other reviewers that the staff is terrific from the people at the desk to the fitness instructors.  My little niece has appeared with me every now and again and the staff seems particularly nice to kids.  Staff gets 4 stars.  Overall if some of the above infrastructure issues get upgraded it'd be an easy call to go up to four stars.

Needs more steep! This gym has lots of cool features but is much more vertical than the other new gyms around.If you like vertical faces this is place for you. If you are into the steep go to Iron Works or Mission Cliffs, or even PG's new gym in Sunnyvale.

Came here for my first rock climbing experience and had a blast! It wasn't crowded, desk people were friendly, and so many different paths to choose to climb. Lower numbers are easier although paths vary - whether straight, or humps to climb over or around. It is definitely a gratifying experience reaching the top. I would def come with friends who know how to belay. Def fun times and I would come back again!

This place has a lot of variety:Indoor climbing (walls & bouldering)YogaA fully gym (cardio, free weights and more)Assorted fitness classesA saunaChanging rooms (with showers)I've been going here for years. The indoor climbing experience is second to none (other than, perhaps, their SF and SJ locations, which are also great).And the variety of workout is fantastic for the price. They get my highest marks.

This rock climbing gym is amazing, and I have been a member for 3 years so far. They have good climbs, both in the top rope and boulder sections. They also have classes for beginners and the staff is really good and helpful. In addition, they have an amazing gym upstairs, which is almost never crowded and the equipment is really good, especially given the fact that their focus is rock climbing. They also have yoga classes and other fitness classes.All in all, if you want to try out rock climbing, or like rock climbing, this place is easily the best out there.

This place is amazing! I love climbing here. I have been here many, many, times and I just love the atmosphere. I have not been to the other PG locations so i cant really compare it to the other locations but its a great place to rock climb or just work out. The routes are great too. They set new ones just in time for me to challenge myself with new courses when I have finished climbing the old ones. It does get pretty crowded in the afternoons, but in the midday its pretty empty especially on weekday's. This is definitely a place to visit if you like climbing or to use the gym!
Compared with the PG in SF and Sunnyvale, this one is kind of a downer. Much smaller and lacking in space, 3 stars.

If you enjoy rock climbing, I would highly recommend the planet granite in Belmont.  The set up is great, you feel like there is a very professional and fun atmosphere.  The staff is very friendly, and you can get to know them on a name basis if you go enough.  All the people who work there (who i've talked to) are climbers and can help you with any questions you have.  The music they play is great.  They play the popular selections during the busy hours, but when there aren't that many people there they will bust out the fun stuff.  I've heard punk, obscure rock, and dubstep while climbing.  The prices aren't too bad, renting shoes costs or a harness is 4.  Both for 7.  It is 17 dollars for unlimited climbing, and 13 if you are a student before 5 and 15 if you aren't.  I enjoy bouldering, and planet granite delivers.  They have two different bouldering rooms with different styles of challenge in each.  One room has higher walls and the other has awkward walls jutting out requiring you to be creative.  The walls in the main room sport top roping and lead climbing, providing fun for the inexperienced as well as the extreme.  The routes are marked at the bottom and shown through colored holds.  If you get the memebership (or pay for the day) you can use their gym as well, or sign up for yoga classes.  The only problem that I find every time I go there is the parking.  The place is in a mostly residential area and they do not have their own parking lot.  It is unlikely there will be a spot right in front, and the Wheel works next door will get mad if you park there during operating hours.  Finding parking can be frustrating at times which makes PG lose a star.  Great place, check it out if you are bored or enjoy climbing.

i can "check" rock climbing off my bucket list now!  i've always been reluctant to pick this sport up because i'm slightly afraid of heights, but with my friends' insistence, i decided to try since i had nothing better to do that day.  the level of difficulty is clearly labeled, so any one can climb -- from 5yr olds to retirees.  i started out scared and shaky, but with each climb, my confidence and comfort grew.  if i can do it, you can too!service was brief and straightforward.  the facility was very clean, nicely ventilated and well-equipped.  however, it was pretty chilly that day, and many wore jackets during their climb.  this place is children friendly so bring your kids here and have them climb until they ache.  for those who do not climb, there's a gym upstairs and i believe they have yoga classes available.  belay certification is only $34.  i highly recommend getting certified esp if you go with friends or slightly more frequently because this will permit you to belay each other.  the people who come are respectful and keep to themselves.

this is by far my favorite climbing place. ok, granted i've only been to the sunnyvale PG and fremont city beach, but still!the staff here is SOOO laid back. i love it. they are friendly and not intimidating at all. when they walk around making sure everyone is doing the right stuff, i don't want to run away and cower in a corner for fear of being scolded. it's awesome.i have to say i really like the routes here too. there's a chimney route that i have grown to like. it hasn't changed for the longest time but every time we go, someone HAS to climb the chimney. there's a speed climb you can try too with cowbells at the top to ring. that's always enjoyable to do. there's also a wall that has different levels, which you can sit and rest on since it is pretty trying. not to mention there's a ledge that you kind of just hop on when doing a 5.10a because you don't know where to go next. we're probably doing it wrong, huh?unlike sunnyvale, the stench of B.O. does not flow in here. i love it even more. when it's a warm day, be prepared to be beat down with the heat. there's no windows so everything is just built up inside. there are fans that they can turn on but i'm not sure if it will be enough to keep me cool. i'll still go here never the less.

*** This is a review of the Planet Garnite Belmont facility and not a reflection of the Sunnyvale and San Francisco location which are far surperior.***I had no problems with this gym when it had only 2 locations, Belmont and Sunnyvale. Belmont just happened to be the lesser of the two. Belmont is closer to me so I didn't mind getting the crappier gym. Then they opened up their San Francisco location. And now it's way too obvious that Belmont gym members are getting the huge shaft. It ticks me off sometimes when I think that we are paying the same monthly rate as San Francisco and Sunnyvale gym members and not getting the same quality facility that they get. Slowly I have seen regulars in Belmont make the trek out to the south bay or the city eventhough Belmont is their closest gym. I don't uderstand how management could let this place deteriorate when it's in one of the most affluent areas in the bay. Can you picture a really old crappy gym in the heart of Beverly Hills or Orange County? Thats what this place is!But let me give you specifics because you guys have no clue of the things that I am complaining about.Weights: The main weight room has a slanted floor! So if u were to put a dumbell on the ground it would start to roll. GHETTO! The machine weights feel dated as well as the cardio equipment. Picture your local 24 hour fitness equipment and think about the equipment they threw away when they upgraded to new stuff. I have this theory that belmont just raided the 24hr fitness garbage can and stole all the old stuff that wasn't up to 24hr fitness standards. But its good enough for Belmont Plant granite I guess. they have this open weight room area that would be pefect for jump rope, lunges, or any other plymetric excercices that require lots of space. Too bad the floor isnt sound proofed and its right underneath the yoga room so any of those are out of the question.Bouldering: Small!!! The only bright side is that they have 2 caves. 1 cave has a larger concentration of V0s and V1s. The other cave has the harder problems and no one under 14 pears or age is allowed in. I like this seperation especially since the weekends have a lot of kids dangeroursly running around the place. But no highball bouldering or top out boulders that the other gyms offer.Roped Climbing: Small!!!! Sunnyvale and San Francisco both have lead climb only sections. Not Belmont. Since the bouldering and top roping are so small, this place gets old real quick! Think abou this. If they are refreshing the problems and routes in Belmont at the same rate as Sunnyvale and San Francisco. Then we are getting far less climbs overall. Their size is 2x as big. Y do we have the same refresh rate as them? 4 or 5 Bouldering Sessions and you're probably done with the amount of projects you can do. But you can be in San Fracnisco and still not finish all your potential projects when they redo the probelms.Yoga: If you're joining the gym just for Yoga purposes then you wouldnt notice a difference in quality. Each gym has different teachers and classes so its all different and a matter of preference. I do know some people that drive all the way to the city for Sarah's Mon and Wed vinyasa flow. And remember, the ceiling is thin so your yoga expereince could get distracted by the sound of people WORKING OUT IN THE WIEGHT ROOM! How dare they!Locker facilites: Homeless people live in more sanitary environments than this. This is the place where SARS was born. Plumbing is always an issue week in and week out. Small lockers so you cant fit an entire wardorbe without wrinkling it. How would you go to this gym before going to work? Filthiest Suana I have seen in my life. The light inside doesnt work which is probably a good thing so you wouldnt notice the true disgustingness of it. To many members doing naked bikram yoga in their. It does get hotter than the saunas in San Francisco which I like. But I think it gets so hot because its busted. The wall clock which was outside the suana room door is broken and hasnt been replaced in 2 weeks. You can buy one in walgreens for 2 bucks! I know, I've purchased one.Staff: OK so the staff is the only bright spot. Cool people.This place has the feel of a gym that could close any second

We were introduced to Planet Granite by a friend and we have now started to come here from time to time. I use this facility to have some bonding time with my son and give him something different to do.  He likes to come here with a friend so they can clown around a bit in the boulder room which does not require a belayer in order to climb.

We booked a babysitter & took belay lessons for a date night. We had so much fun with the instructor & scaling the walls after wards. If it wasn't for our out of shape arms we would have gone all night. Definitely will be back with our kid when he is older. This would be a great family activity!

I'm all about this place, it's always a treat to climb here.  I used to climb at their Santa Clara location but this one seems to be quite a bit bigger and more up to date.  The bouldering section is always cool yet challenging.  This location also seems to have higher ceilings than PG Santa Clara which is always nice!  My favorite are the overhangs, they're hard, but not impossible.  I've only had a chance to check out the climbing area but I noticed they also have a Yoga room and exercise bikes (among other things I'm sure).  The staff is knowledgeable and helpful when needed.

Came here the first time and the place was clean and well maintained. the employees very friendly and the rental equipment were decent. the climbing areas are spread out pretty well so that there was plenty of room to not be others way.

This climbing gym is fun for beginners like myself but also for the pros that seem to be covering every square inch of the walls there... The belay class  is only $5 but if you are not a member you'll also have to pay $17 for the day and about $5 for shoe/harness rental. The people that work in this gym are very friendly and helpfull. On Fridays you can get in for only $8 if you are a student and it is a fun way to spend your Friday night with friends. Climb on!

A great gym in the peninsula if you're a climber. I started climbing there but then one by one my friends eventually stopped going. My dilemma, no belay partner! Although you can always sign up and find one at the gym, I'm not much into having someone I don't know belay me. Now my poor barely broken in climbing shoes and harness are just gathering dust in the closet. There's a couple bouldering areas so that's always a nice option. The cardio and weight areas upstairs are fairly small but it never gets too crowded and you probably wouldn't really have to wait for a machine. You also get a good view upstairs of the climbers on the wall. Great entertainment. The yoga classes that I've been to were also excellent. Very well worth it if you take advantage of it. Not really worth it if you're just going to work out here. Well worth it if you climb or practice yoga.

Reasonable prices, safety is required as they don't let anyone climb the vertical wall unless they pass a safety test, nice and clean facilities, wasn't crowded during the weekday when I went. I looked at pictures of the new site in SF, and I must say it does look impressive. I'm strongly leaning in getting a membership now.

The facility itself is great and the staff are really nice. Classes are good but noise can be a problem. I've been climbing here for 2 years and keep coming back. Not as big as the other 2.Weekdays are packed after 6:30 pm. Weekend mornings people bring their kids and there are birthday parties. I have no problem with the parties. The gym does their best to monitor them. The problem are parents who bring their kids don't keep an eye on them. It is a family friendly place but if you plan on bringing your kids be sure you have 3 adult climbers so your belayer isn't distracted from belaying. It isn't a great place to bring very young children but it is GREAT if your kids are old enough to climb.
This place rocks. i Love this place. people who work here are friendly and there is no better place to climb and meet new people. very addicting
Definitely a terrific place to work out.  Besides climbing, there's a gym, yoga classes, and a sauna. Best gym in the area.

Even though I hear this gym is way smaller than the Sunnyvale location, I love the feel and laid-back nature of this gym.  The smaller size lends itself nicely to a more productive climbing experience.  Also the caves are nice for fooling around on (another side effect of not being as crowded as Mission Cliffs).I was hesitant about a membership at Mission Cliffs (after multiple visits) even though I live in the city and one trip to Planet Granite has got me looking for climbing buddies willing to make the trip to Belmont ;)

I organized a work event here recently, opting for the group to receive 2 hours of training with the instructors. The staff did a great job, considering a majority of the group had never rock climbed before. We learned proper belaying technique and safety before starting our ascension up the various routes. I think everyone left with a solid knowledge of belaying and a newfound appreciation for the activity. The facility seemed great, though as a novice, I have no other rock climbing places to compare it with it. I appreciated the fact the group had access to the rest of the facility (the exercise equipment and studio classes) following our lesson. From an event organizer's perspective, it's unfortunate they don't have a party room where you can bring food in, but there are several restaurants within a one mile vicinity of the gym to visit afterwards.

The gym and fitness equipment here are adequate, and being able to watch the climbers definitely helps the time go by faster when you're on the cardio machines.However, the real reason I go to PG is for the climbing.  The gym has a good variety of routes -- a bit of something for everyone, from the kiddie routes to the 5.12+ climbs with long overhangs to slabby climbs on the contoured walls that simulate natural rock features.  The staff are friendly and approachable, and the climbing classes were definitely helpful for me.  The people who climb here are a friendly bunch, and I've made some good friends (and climbing partners) here.It seems there are fewer climbs here than at PG Sunnyvale, but this location is also much less crowded.

Ouch! is what I have to say after trying climbing for the first time here tonight.  Who knew climbing up a sheer wall could be so fun?  This place is big and well lit, has lots of room and lots of routes of varying difficulty, and it was pretty impressive watching some of the better climbers contort their bodies into odd, pretzel-like shapes trying to reach that one tiny little handhold off to the side.  The staff here is also friendly and helpful.  If you like pain or your forearms have misbehaved and need to be punished, then this is the place to go!

love this place.visited once with daughter but was not able to take advantage of the membership yet.love the yoga and the fun atmosphere.Daughter only did bouldering for an hour but LOVED IT.We will return as soon as we get belay certified.

i was a gym member of the belmont PG while working in san carlos.  i never rock climbed but did partake in yoga classes and other weight training classes they offered.the yoga studio is a good size and the instructors are great.  the classes are small and personable.  i would always go in the morning before heading to work.  after yoga i would go up and do a little cardio and weight training.  because their gym is so small you don't get a bunch of meat heads running around, nor do you have to wait around for machines.  the changing rooms and showers are pretty clean.  they also have a sauna.i miss planet granite!

I have written previous reviews for PG Sunnyvale and San Francisco and I can only repeat myself for the Belmont location. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable and so are the yoga and fitness teachers. There are plenty of classes to choose from in the morning and evening and as a member you can use their other locations as well. I'd recomend this gim definitively to any climber but as well without a doubt to non-climbers who like yoga and fitness!

I'd highly recommend Planet Granite in Belmont if you're a rock climber or into yoga; both offer an intimate setting with knowledgeable and friendly staff.  But what I really love the most about this place are the circuit training and abs & core classes led by Harriete Estel Berman.  I've spent years happily turning myself over to her butt-kicking, fun classes that make me sweaty and strong with endorphins galore going off.   I only wish I didn't have an inflexible job so I could go to the circuit training class every Monday, Wednesday and Friday morning.  Its absolutely perfect for ADD types like me who would look out the window at a squirrel if left to my own devices in a room full of gym equipment.
