in the summer for me this place is 4 stars with a couple missing for occasionally rude workers, and too many broken machines at one time. i luvd this place til winter, then it got COLD and theres no heat at all its FREEZING. if i wanted to work out in the cold i would just work out in the great outdoors...also they dont turn their lights on in the daytime and it is often so dark it is difficult to read while biking or treadmilling or whatever. its kinda depressing not having the lights on. in the summer when it was sunny it was almost ok, but in the winter when its dark and cold and theres no sun, the last thing i want is to go into a freezing place with no lighting. its just weird. i agree w some others that have postulated that perhaps they are on the brink of going out of business. i wonder if any of their locations have heat or if thats just the climbing culture? anyway im sad to have to leave but its looking like im going to have to head over to fitness 19. hopefully they will have the good sense to turn on the lights and heat the place. wish me luck. :)

I joined PG about 4 months ago, the Belmont one at least. I would recommend going around 1 pm, when there is nobody there to climb. If you don't know anything about this sport, they have several types of classes. To do anything there you need to take a belaying class (I think it's $17). But belaying is only using the pulley attached to your harness to lower someone, and keep the rope taut as your climber climbs. The actual climbing is learned by doing. My advice, watch the girls, they have a tendency to use thier legs, men tend to try to muscle everything around. That and trust your equipment, if you do, how high, how hard, doesn't really matter. The rope you use has a tensile strength to hold 4000lbs, so it could hold a  Jeep Grand Cherokee in the air. It's pricey (I pay $70 a month), but it's $20 to climb if you're not a member, and another $5 for gear. If you go 3 times, you might as well join. It's also a great way to work out and not realize it.
Another great Bay Area climbing gym.  Not quite as large as Mission Cliffs in the city, but still a reasonable amount of routes for all skill levels.  Planet Granite has a decent fitness gym, too.

I tend to join a gym and quit a few months later, but don't plan on leaving this "gym."  Its great that they have a large climbing facility with a gym and yoga classes, even a sauna in the changing rooms.  I have yet to take a yoga class or really use the gym upstairs, but I love the rock climbing aspect.  It always appears and smells clean (more than I can say for other gyms).  I look forward to being a member for years to come and eventually trying a Saturday yoga class.

I have a fitness only membership to PG, and have been going since the beginning of the year.  This will mainly be a fitness/yoga review: To begin the review, I'll start with some positives:* The front desk staff are all really nice.  It's important for people to smile and greet you when you give them your card to scan in right?* The facility is well-maintained.  There are lockers to put your things in.* They have a nice fitness facility.  I can always get on the machine I want.* Unlimited yoga/abs/fitness classes, which comes down to less than five dollars per class if you go 2-3 times a week.Some things I try really hard to ignore:* The locker rooms are older, and showers can be disgusting at times.  * Bring your own towels.  Their towels have turned "beige-y" in color from too many washes, and are not soft at all.* The fitness classes are packed (due to them having great instructors).  There really should be a limit of how many people are allowed in the class at one time.  Classes sometime can be mat-to-mat, and can be an issue if you have long legs/arms, or just tall.* People like to come late to the fitness classes ALL THE TIME.  They seem to wander in 10-15 minutes AFTER the class has begun, lay their mats down, and start talking to the person next to them as if class hasn't started.* On a side note, there are a couple frequent members that likes to make noises during yoga.  We're not talking about quiet grunt noises...  we're talking out loud "ahhhhhhs" and "uggghhhhhhhs" continuously for 40 minutes.  I'm not into hearing other people moan, so it may just be me.Overall, great instructors, great staff, and you never have to wait around for gym equipments.  However, they need to limit the # of students per yoga class, and not allowing students to come in so late.

I've been climbing at this gym for just over a year now and i think its great considering there aren't any other gyms on the peninsula. I climb mostly sport, boulder some, and use the exercise equipment every time i go. The sport routes here are pretty good under the lead cave and the only real problem i have is that they set routes that traverse the whole wall and climbers leading those routes end up taking up the whole wall. I know they restrict those routes during peak times but even off those times it gets really annoying. The ratings here are on the easy side and some times the consistency is off. There would be a 11a that would be incredibly technical and difficult and a 11- that would be like a walk in the park almost. Last thing about the lead climbing is that the lead test i think is to easy at this gym so there are a lot of people who shouldn't be lead climbing here. I think the minimum requirement for the lead test is to climb a 5.8 which is ridiculous. The bouldering is ok here. If you're really into bouldering go to the newer gym in Sunnyvale. The walls are much more "boulder" like. The exercise equipment is great at this gym, only thing is it gets crowded at the peak hours from 6-9pm. But overall if you're looking for a climbing gym on the peninsula this one is pretty good. If you looking to join look out for the membership sale. No initiation fee is great.
